categories: Fantasy, Horror, Miniatures, Science Fiction, Wargame

name: ROC 'n Lol
description:
ROC 'n Lol is Dutch game designed for a school (ROC). It is actually a two-in-one-game, since the game can be played in two different ways.

1. Party and play
Can be played by two to five teams of two players each. Each team moves it's pawn by rolling a die and performing different actions (answering questions, guessing words, drawing pictures). Winner is the first team to reach the finish line.

2. Topper Coach
Can be played by 2 to 5 players. Each player has six students that need to graduate. These six students are guided through their education by playing out cards. Winner is the first player graduating all six students.

About the game name:
"ROC" is the name of the school type.
"Lol" is the Dutch word for "fun".
mechanics: Open Drafting, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Chestnut Burrs
description: Four cards of the same design, numbered from 1 to 4, constitute a book. The winner of the game is the player having the most books at the end of play.

name: Vegas the Game
description: This is a roll & move game in which certain spaces allow the player to make a roulette bet, throw craps, play a hand of black jack, or play the slots. The slots are played via flipping cards. The game comes with 100 plastic poker chips in 4 colors. The winner is the first to $20,000 or 1/5 of the chips.

name: Crossword Letter Game
description:
A spelling game from the 1930s, which might best be described as a 'free-form' Scrabble. There are 48, 64 or 96 cards in different versions of this game. (The unrelated earlier Crossword Card Game had 52 cards.)

Cards are dealt, and each player spells words, attaching them to any existing words in "crossword" fashion. The first player to get rid of all their cards wins the round, and the other players add the value of their remaining cards to their score. Games ends when someone reaches 100 points, and LOW SCORE wins.

The letter cards, how many of each (2nd column) in a 96-card set, and their point values (3rd column):


Free 2 10 I 2 8 R 4 6
A 6 8 J 2 4 S 6 6
B 2 4 K 2 6 T 6 6
C 4 6 L 6 6 U 4 6
D 2 4 M 4 6 V 2 4
E 8 8 N 4 6 W 4 6
F 2 2 O 6 6 X 2 1
G 4 2 P 2 6 Y 2 2
H 4 6 Q 2 2 Z 2 1

name: Nation's Treasures
description:
Nation's Treasures is a card game inspired by Lost Cities.
While retaining the classic Lost Cities 2-player rule, the game is designed with new 3-4 player rule. In new 3-4 player rule:
Cards are separated into 5 decks according to colors.
In the setup, players draw 2 cards randomly and flips the top card of each deck, then chooses to draw 2 cards.
Each time the top card is drawn, you flip up the top card.
mechanics: Hand Management, Open Drafting, Set Collection

name: Uncharted Lands
description:
So what is it all about? The Uncharted Lands is a fantasy combat game that uses 28mm scale white metal miniatures. But it is also MUCH more than just a range of well sculpted figures.

The Uncharted Lands will act as the backdrop for all of our fantasy games, including our naval combat game.

The first races to be supported are Iron Dwarves and Orc Raiders. But we’re underway with our Humans and Dragon Lords. Shortly we will be making our Halfling Militia available and over time more races from The Uncharted Lands will appear.

We are developing a set of rules for the game and we hope to have more news for you on when these rules will be available. Right now we have 9 packs of miniatures (5 Iron Dwarf and 4 Orc Raiders) complete, each with 4 figures for foot troops or 3 figures for command.

We have greens for new figures, including an Orc commander and his brutish bodyguard and a cannon and crew for the Dwarves. We are busy with the design of our Dragon Lords and Humans, both races we’re sure you’ll like when they arrive.

Over time The Uncharted Lands will grow and new races will begin to unfold. The combination of naval game and land game is a novel one and we’re sure you’ll enjoy both. The Gallery below will give you an idea of what our miniatures look like when painted.

name: TAKO
description:
OBJECT OF GAME: The player to make the last legal move wins.

START: Make two piles of l1 stones. Each player rolls the die. Whoever rolls the highest value makes the first
move.

PLAY: Each player starts his/her turn by flipping a coin. If the coin lands heads up then the turn must be TAKO
HI. And if the coin lands tails up the turn must be TAKO LO. TAKO HI and TAKO LO affect how many stones
the player can remove from each pile in this turn. Then the player rolls the die and makes note of the value. Next
the player must make a legal move. Legal moves consist of:
1. Taking any number of stones from one pile.
2. Taking an equal number of stones from both piles.
3. Using an option move.

THE DESIGNER SAYS: As far as I can recall this is the first game I created that I actually committed to paper. I believe I created this game in 1992 or 1993. Based loosely on a mathematical game called Tsianshidsi, TAKO is a silly time wasting game.

According to the rules sheet, TAKO is pronounced take-o.

Full Rules Here:
http://gnomegaming.com/ourgames

name: Balancing Bob
description: Balancing Bob sits atop a ladder mounted on a pivoting base. Each player has three plastic paint cans that hook onto the ladder. Based on a die roll, players move their cans up the ladder and eventually hang them on one of Bob's outstretched feet. The first player to get all three of their cans onto Bob's feet without tipping over the ladder wins.

name: Bee Bops
description: Bee Bops features a motorized flower patch. When activated, the flowers' pedals open to reveal "nectar disks". Each player has, according to the rules, a "stick-on trigger action bee". The trigger extends an arm with a suction cup at its end, which is used to collect the nectar disks. The player who retrieves the most nectar wins.

name: Safari Friends
description: This children's game requires no reading, but helps to learn the animal names. Each player is given a "character card" depicting an elephant, giraffe, tiger, or zebra. Players attempt to create a copy of their animal out of four square tiles. The tiles start stacked face down on cards depicting one of eight other animals. On their turn, a player spins a spinner to determine which animal's stack they may draw from to find one of their missing animal pieces. The player completing their animal first wins.

name: The Journey to Bethlehem
description:
Game parts:

12 1/2 x 15 1/2 heavy folded board
Six pointed star spinner
3 wisemen on camels
3 shepherds

Game board shows the location of 145 Historic Places Famous in Bible History. The object of the game is to travel the roads and the first to get all their pieces to Bethlehem first wins.

name: Im-Bi-Bo
description:
extrapolated from Fair Play Games description.

This is a simple, abstract game of strategy for two. Each turn players place cards on a small board hoping to pick up stones and, at the same time, control the value of those stones so they'll have the most points at the end of the game.

name: The Shadow of a Dark God
description:
"The players will discover that the death of a friend is linked to a mysterious cult worshiping an immensely ancient deity."

The players control parties of six adventurers investigating the death of a good friend. The investigation leads the parties to search a cult temple. Hazards that may be faced by the adventurers include Rats, Traps, and the Horrible Old Ones.

A Cthulhu-inspired WarpQuest game to be played using the Artifact Core Rules.

name: Mummys Tomb
description:
Each player controls a party of six adventuring archaeologists and treasure hunters searching for a Pharaoh's treasure.

The parties journey through Egypt's Nile River Valley until they reach the Mummy's Tomb, which must then be explored. Hazards that may be faced by the adventurers include Sandstorms, Stubborn Camels, Serpent People, and the Mummy's Curse.

The party which exits the Nile River Valley with the Golden Treasure of the Pharaoh wins the game.

A WarpQuest game to be played using the Artifact Core Rules.

name: Quest for the Grail
description:
Each player is a Knight of the Round Table searching for the Holy Grail. Knights are rated in a number of categories: Chivalry, Valor, Ranger, Sorcery, Seamanship, Wisdom, War, and Strength. Hazards that may be faced by the Knights include Mordred, the Black Knight, Plague, Brigands, and Pirates.

Played using the WarpQuest game system.
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Variable Player Powers

name: Pirate Island
description:
Each player controls a pirate Expedition consisting of a captain, ship, and crew. An Expedition is rated for a number of characteristics: Crew, Cannon, Navigation, Discipline, Sailing, and Swashbuckling. Hazards that may be faced by the Expeditions include Spanish Galleons, Typhoons, Volcanic Eruptions, and Hostile Natives. The winner is the player who returns with the buried treasure.

Played using the WarpQuest game system.

name: Greek Heroes
description:
"Each player controls a Greek Hero on a Quest to retrieve the Golden Fleece."

Each Hero is rated for a number of skills, including Wit, Strength, Archery, Swordsmanship, and Navigation. These skills are used to overcome foes and tests which face the Heroes, such as the Minotaur, Kraken, Labyrinth, Amazons, and Hydra.

Played using the WarpQuest game system.

name: Hidalgo
description:
"Based on the Movie Hidalgo. Horse Race across the Arabian Desert. Each player (Pawn) represents a Rider & Horse."

The game is played on a track 50 spaces long, along which the players face survival and fighting challenges. The first player to reach the end of the track wins the race.

Played using the WarpQuest game system.
categories: Adventure, Animals, Arabian, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Racing

name: Surviving the Gulag
description:
"The year is 1947 and the player is an Estonian patriot and resistance fighter that has been caught by the Russians and transported to Siberia to a brutal labor camp. The sentence is ten years of horrific conditions. The player has to survive the camp to return to the beloved Estonia."

"Resistance Fighter, Kalle Loodus, 33 years of age, former corporal in the Estonian Army during the independence, fought in Finnish Army during the War of Continuation, after the war returned to the Soviets by Finnish communist traitors, escaped and fought as a 'Forest Brother Guerilla Fighter' until caught and sent to labor camp in Siberia."

Hardships that may face the player include Scurvy, Tuberculosis, Forced Labor, and Torture.

Played using the WarpQuest game system.

name: War Over the Reich
description:
"Each player controls a Flight of 300 British (Halifax, Wellington, Mosquito, and Lancaster) Bombers on a Night Raid to bomb targets in Nazi Germany."

The players must get their Flight to the target, bomb the target, and return. The object is to earn the most victory points. Victory points are awarded for destroying targets and destroying enemy fighters. Victory points are lost when bombers are destroyed.

A variant set of cards is included to cover American daylight bombing raids.

Played using the WarpQuest game system.
categories: Card Game, Fighting, Print & Play, World War II

name: Destroy the Rail Road Bridge
description:
"The player controls a combat team of 5 Finnish Army Recon (Kaukopartio in Finnish) men in a mission far behind Soviet lines. The mission is to destroy a Rail Road Bridge 60 miles behind the enemy lines. It´s January 1943 and it's cold and dark in the Karelian woods."

"Each party consists of 5 members: Sergeant V.Korpi, Corpral J.Lahtinen, Jaeger M.Koskinen, Jaeger S.Berg, Jaeger S.Stenstrom. The Sergeant has 3 skills, Corpral has 2 skills and Jaegers have 1 skill. The combat team is armed with 5 Suomi SMG's, 1 Sniper Rifle, Satchel Charges (AT weapon), mines, knives (the puukko's) and hand grenades. The team is carrying a radio. The team is skiing 60 miles to the target and 60 miles back to the Finnish lines."

The object of the game is to get your team safely to the bridge so that you can destroy it and then return. "When the combat team reaches home, they take a good 3 hour sauna bath, sleep a little and start another mission."

Played using the WarpQuest game system.
categories: Card Game, Print & Play, World War II

name: Palace of the Silver Princess
description:
"This Warp Quest Adventure is adapted from the D&D Basic Adventure Module Palace of the Silver Princess."

Each player chooses to play one of the following characters: Human Paladin, Dwarf Fighter, Aasimar Cleric, Human Wizard, or Elf Bard. The winner is the first player to reach the end of the thirty space long track on the game board. Along the way the players will face randomly drawn traps and monsters.

Played using the WarpQuest game system.
mechanics: Role Playing, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Score
description:
"Each player takes the role of a teenager looking to Score on a Saturday night."

The players move pawns down a thirty space track facing an assortment of challenges: alcohol, sex, drugs, music, trouble and fight. When you win a challenge, you keep the Challenge Card. The player who acquires the most cards in the most challenge types wins the game.

Played using the WarpQuest game system.

name: Barney Musical Parade Game
description: This is a simple roll-and-move game for very young children. Players roll an oversized die and move to the next space with a matching shape. The die is electronic and plays the "I Love You" song, adding incessant joy to the game. The first player to reach the end of the path wins.
categories: Children's Game, Electronic, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Great Dynasties of Europe
description:
"Theme: European Royal Houses 1300-1900. Each turn represents 25 years (roughly 1 generation). Starting in 1300 and ending in 1900. There are 24 turns."

There are three custom card decks used in the game, the Dynasty Deck, Territory Deck, and Event Deck.

The Dynasty Deck represents the Dynasties that the players can represent. Each Dynasty has a starting Territory and a Special Ability. The Dynasties included in the game are: Habsburg, Orange, Tudor, Burgundy, Stuart, Romanov, Grimaldi, Hohenzollern, Oldenburg, Bourbon, Capetian, and Valois.

Each card in the Territory Deck represents a Territory that can be owned by a player. Each Territory belongs to one of ten Regions.

The Event Deck contains a variety of random events. Each turn a card is drawn from the Event Deck and resolved.

"Victory: The player with the most Victory Tokens at the end of the game wins."

name: R辿volution
description:
Contents: 8 sand timers, 1 board with 34 holes.

The game starts with the hourglasses set at opposite sides of the board, and each player at his turn moves and flips one of his 4 sand times along the lines of the board. Any hourglass out of sand is considered dead and pulled out of the game. The goal is to reach the opposite line of starting holes.

name: Ripost
description:
Contents : The board is a map representing two enemy territories, one lake, mountains, forests, roads, rivers, two citadels and 4 towns. Each player has 24 pawns: 8 infantry, 4 cavalry, 4 artillery, 3 engineering, 3 train, 2 infirmary. Also 2 special dices, several season cards, and map tokens.
This is a simplified wargame, with each side trying to take the opponents citadel or his two towns. Each turn, the player has 10 points that he might use to move his pawns, then if the target is in reach, he can fire.
The cards trigger events that affect the map (forest fires, plagues, etc.) Terrain also influences the way the pieces can move, and their vulnerability.

name: Immortals
description:
“Each player recruits a group of Immortals seeking to gain power over other such groups. Based on the Dungeons & Dragons RPG rule set ‘Wrath of the Immortals’. These associations of Immortals are variously known as Groups, Cliques (informal), and Councils (formal).”

The players represent a specific alignment: Lawful, Chaotic, or Neutral. Alignment affects the types of immortals which may be recruited by a player.

The winner is the first player to control one hundred Power Points worth of Immortals and Resource cards. A player may also win by reducing all opposing players to zero Power Points.

name: Cosmic Tilt
description:
Each player takes the role of an alien psychic and battles to be the last brain thinking. The magazine article included rules for the game, record sheets, and six special characters. Play also requires a standard deck of playing cards and some tokens.

The game was published October 18, 2002 in Pyramid Magazine.
categories: Card Game, Print & Play, Science Fiction
publishers: (Web published), Pyramid Magazine, Steve Jackson Games

name: ECOnomia
description:
ECOnomia is a game where each player is the CEO of a major corporation and throughout the turns they must add companies to their holdings by buying them, increasing their economic power.
The problem is that on times of growing pollution levels, and the sustainability of our planet at stake, the CEOs must show their alignment with the preservation tendencies, sustainability measures and social responsibility. As so they must meet the emission levels set by the government, paying higher taxes for higher emission levels with caution not to exceed the limit established. The winner of this game is the CEO who manages to get the most "Green Points" (victory points) by choosing carefully the companies they bought, by cleaning their plants with the usage of technologies and by doing environmental initiatives.

The game takes place in eight turns, and each turn is divided in the following phases: Event, Investment, Technology Acquisition, Revenue, Government Taxes & Subsidies

Event: on the beginning of each turn a random event is drawn and affects all the players.
Investment: Each player may buy a company of their choice (each company have in their tile the company cost, the revenue per turn, the emission level and how many green points it's worth)
Technology: technologies that improve the revenue points or reduce emissions may be bought by the players though auctions.
Revenue: Each player collect the revenue of their companies.
Taxes & Subsidies: Each player pays the taxes due or collects the subsidies if eligible to.


At the end of the 8th round the player with most green points wins the game.

Home Page: http://www.riachuelogames.com.br/economia/ (Portuguese)

name: Man-Kzin Wars
description:
“Solo card game based on the stories in Known Space by Larry Niven. The player is playing to defeat the Kzinti and save the Human Race.”

“The Situation: The Warlike Kzinti are attacking human Space. The Pacifist Humans at this time have inferior technology, however, the Kzin have a Large Empire to control & their military traditions of Honor result in Hasty attacks by overconfident, small forces in search of personal glory. If the Humans can hold out, they can improve their technology and gain the advantage.”

The game is played using a custom deck of cards and a board consisting of a twelve space track. The first space on the track represents the Earth and the last space represents the Kzinti Home Worlds.

“Victory: If the Kzinti Expansion Marker (KEM) ever reaches earth, the Kzinti win. If the KEM reaches the Home Worlds, the Humans win.”

name: Making Plays
description:
“2 player card game. Simulation of an American Football game ... As in regular football, the player with the most points at the end of the game wins.”

The game uses a custom deck of cards made up of seven types of cards: Run, Pass, Kick, Blitz, Offense, Defense, and Special. Cards are played to gain Field Position Tokens which represent the offensive player’s position on the field, from the player’s goal line (zero tokens), to midfield (three tokens), to a touchdown (seven tokens). Down Tokens are used to track change of possession on downs, which occurs after the Offensive Player accumulates five of the tokens. Whenever the Offensive Player gains a Field Position Token, all but one of the Down Tokens are discarded.

Each player begins with a hand of five cards, and draws three cards at the start of each turn. The Offensive Player declares whether there will be a regular play, punt, or field goal attempt. The Defensive Player may play a Blitz Card. If the Blitz Card cannot be countered by the Offensive Player, the play is over. If a regular play was declared, the Offensive Player then declares either a running play or a pass play, and plays either a Pass or Run Card. If the card is not countered by the Defensive Player, the Offensive Player can play one additional card to increase the yardage of the play. A Run Card can be used to extend either type of play, but a Pass Card can only be used to extend a Pass play.

When an Offensive Player accumulates seven or more Field Position Tokens, a touchdown is scored and the Offensive Player receives six points. The point after touchdown attempt is governed by a die roll, as are punts, field goals, and kick offs.

name: Laff-a-Lympics
description:
“Card game for 3 Players. 3 Teams of Cartoon Characters compete in Sporting Events. Based on the Hanna-Barbara cartoon of the same name.”

The three teams are the Scooby-Doobeys, Yogi Yahooeys, and Really Rottens. Each team has a unique Team Deck of cards. All of the teams share a common Antics Deck of cards.

Each hand of cards equals one Laff-a-Lympics episode. Each Episode has four sports events. Team and Antics cards are used to bid on an event. Taking first place in an event earns 25 points, second place earns 15 points, and third place earns 10 points. The team with the most points in four events wins the Episode.
categories: Card Game, Humor, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Sports

name: Lupin
description:
“Card Game for 2+ Players. Based on the Animated Series Lupin the Third. Each player is a version of Lupin and his companions. Players race to complete Escapades.”

The first player to complete four Escapades wins the game. Escapades include Heists, Rescues, and Showdowns. To complete an Escapade, a player must play a meld of cards having a higher total Combat or Con value than the corresponding values on the Escapade in play (and any attached Complications cards.)
categories: Card Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Incal
description:
“Card game for 2 players. Based on the Graphic Novel ‘The Incal’ by Moebius.”

A futuristic battle between the forces of the Light Side, led by John DiFool, and the Dark Side. A player wins the game by causing the opposing player to run out of cards. In addition, the Light Side player can win by playing a “win card” which provides an automatic victory if the forces of the Dark Side do not prevail within seven more turns.
categories: Card Game, Comic Book / Strip, Science Fiction

name: Jorune
description:
"Board & card game for 2+ players. Takes place in the 'Jorune' RPG universe. Each player controls a young human (Tauther) from the realm of Burdoth, wishing to become a Citizen (Drenn). This requires a quest (Tothis). During the quest the Tauther will acquire marks on their Tablet (& Challisk) called Copra."

The object of the game is to be the first player to accumulate 20 Copra.

name: KND Missions
description:
A card game for two or more players based on the Kids Next Door cartoon series.

The object of the game is to be the first player to accumulate 100 Mission Points by completing missions. Mission Cards are assigned point values ranging from 15 to 25 based on the difficulty of the mission. Missions include “Count Spankulot on the Rampage”, “Villainous Ice Cream Men”, “Tapioca Mystery”, and “Compete in Annual Toobathon River Race.”

Missions are completed by discarding a set of cards (the "Mission Team") having a point value equal to or greater than point value of the Mission Card. A Mission Team is made up of at least one Basic Agent and any number of Allies and Tech cards.
categories: Card Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Kings Gambit
description: A combination of two classic games! In this Chess/Poker variant, the luck of the draw is as important as skillful chess play. The game is played using a standard chess set and deck of playing cards. All the rules of chess apply except for turn order. Instead of alternating moves between black and white, each turn the players play a hand of Draw Poker. The winner of the poker hand gets to move one of his own pieces.

name: Kings Men Backgammon
description:
"Backgammon Variant. Wargaming Elements. Medieval Theme."

"Each player starts with 12 Men: 1 King, 2 Knights, and 9 other Men. You have 40 points to spend on the 9 other Men." There are twenty-two different units, each rated for hit points, attack strength, and special ability (if any.) Units include Powder Keg bombs, Horse Archers, Berserkers, Crossbowmen, and Catapults.

The object of the game is to destroy the opposing King.

name: Hullabaloo the game: A trivia game about Aggieland
description:
Players travel around a board decorated with drawings of Texas A&M University images trying to answer trivia questions correctly to gain 4 differently colored pieces that spell out T.A.M.U. The first player to collect all four pieces and make his way back to the center of the board wins.
Each colored piece corresponds to one of four trivia categories: Traditions & History, Campusology & The Corps, Sports, and Academics.
The game can be played with teams.

name: Interstellar Pig
description:
"Card & Board game for 2-4 players. Find the Interstellar Pig or your entire race is doomed. This game is based on an imaginary game of the same name described in a novel of the same name written by William Sleator."

Each player starts with a character, four planets, and a random set of Attribute cards. The players travel from planet to planet collecting additional Attribute cards. If you kill an opposing player, you take all of that player's Attribute cards and the player is eliminated from the game.

The game lasts sixteen rounds. The player holding the Interstellar Pig Attribute card at the end of the game wins.

name: Mexico City Campaign
description:
Mexico City Campaign is a two player board game simulating the last month of fighting in the Mexican-American war (1846-1847) covering the period from mid-August to mid-September 1847. Following the invasion of Mexico that had started a year before in the north, US General Winfield Scott and his army arrived from Puebla in the eastern side of Mexico City to a village called Ayotla.

In Mexico City campaign one player takes control of the US army under the command of General Scott, and the other player takes control of the Mexican Army under the command of General Santa Anna, and each player moves his provided counters in an attempt to fulfill victory conditions as set out further below. The game commences on 12th August 1847 following the US arrival and finishes on 13th September 1847 unless the automatic victory conditions are fulfilled by either player.

This conflict simulation comes with the following components:
• Simulation Map
• Counters: Combat Units, Non-Combat Units and Mark Counters.
• Game Rules

Additionally players will need a 6 sided dice for combat resolution.

name: TravFuda
description:
Retheme and redesign of Hanafuda.
10 suits of 6 cards, with Traveller inspired artwork.

play is derivative from Hana-awase and Koi-Koi.

Mechanics of play: play one card from hand, and one card from top of deck to tableau; if a card played is matched by suit, stack on top of match. Pick up any stacks with even numbers of matched tiles.

Scoring is by set collection. Sets are themed.

available at: http://aramis.hostman.us/games/
direct download: http://aramis.hostman.us/games/TravFudaComplete.pdf
categories: Card Game, Print & Play, Science Fiction

name: Death Ride of the Panzers
description:
Death Ride of the Panzers - The German Attack on the Southern Shoulder of the Kursk Salient

Death Ride of the Panzers is a board game simulating the operations conducted by 4th Panzer Army and Army Detachment Kempf as part of Operation Citadel these formations were to form the southern pincer of the German assault. Operation Citadel was an attempt by the Germans to eliminate the Kursk Salient on the Eastern Front thus shortening the front line that needed to be held. As well as the hope of being able to destroy a large amount of Red Army forces thus dissipating their ability to conduct offensive operations in the coming winter. The battle simulated took place from the 5th July to the 13th July 1943.

The game consists of a map, 124 counters (1 turn counter, 48 German ground and air unit counters and the soviets have a total of 75 ground and air unit counters), 2 dice and a rule document.
categories: Print & Play, Wargame, World War II

name: Chain Gang
description:
From the website:

Link dice across a unique playing field to outscore your opponent.

Chain Gang is simple but challenging dice scoring game. Players roll four dice and then put two of the dice scores into hexes on the score pad to form "chains" of dice. Create the longest chain you can while simultaneously blocking your opponent from making his or her own chains.

name: Bear & Bull
description:
The game has been developed by Identity Games in Rotterdam for Robeco as a promotional game.

The goal of the game is to accumulate several victory points. Points are scored in several ways:
1. By investing a full 100% (in steps of 25%) in a economic sector.
2. With special strategy cards worth 1 point. When you land on a strategy field you can pick up 1 card.
3. By investing in different areas at the same time around the world.
4. By investing in all sectors at the same time (regardless of area)

The game shares several similarities with Monopoly, like roll-and-move, buying assets, completing sets, drawing cards when landed on certain fields on the board. There are also some differences, for example you can takeover someone's assets when you land on his field and he has no full set yet.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Beat the Reaper
description: A card game where one player takes on the role of the Reaper (IRS) and the other players are taxplayers (wordplay on taxpayer). Players try to bluff the reaper on card values (deductions) that can increase money bag values. If the reaper catches a bluff (audit he get the card value for himself. The first player to accumulate 150,000 wins the game.

name: Militaire
description:
Militaire is an army card game, consisting of 54 cards representing the ranks of the British Army.

The object of the game is to make up sets of three or four cards of a kind or a run of 3, 4, 6 or 7 cards in order of rank.

The first player to expose a complete hand comprising:
a) Two sets, or
b) a set and a run, or
c) an unbroken run of 6 or 7 cards,
wins the round and scores bonus points.

name: Planet Earth Card Game
description:
Which country is the Giant Panda native to: Japan, China or India? Discover how much you really know about the natural world as you play the Planet Earth Card Game.

Based on the BBC series of the same name, this card is an educational card game, suitable for all ages.
categories: Card Game, Educational, Environmental, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Oregon Trivia Game
description: Be the first player to get to the level 5 center of the board to win. Along the way, answer questions about the great town of Oregon, IL

name: Ball and Chain
description:
Ball and Chain is a set of fantasy skirmish rules for 15mm and 25mm scale miniatures.
They are purely a generic set of rules which has a design system that lets you to decide on what type of troops you want. It has also a magic system and ideas on monsters.

name: Man O'Warp
description:
“Card game based on the Games Workshop Game called Man O' War.”

Each player constructs a fleet from one of the ship lists, with each player using an equal number of points. There are ships for the Bretonnian, Empire, Dwarf, High Elf, and Orc fleets. The object of the game is to destroy all of the ships in the opposing fleet.

name: Matrix Conquest
description:
“The Matrix: Movie theme. Board game for 4 players.”
Each player choose to play one of the four Factions: The Architect, Mister Smith, The Merovingian, or Zion & the Oracle. Each Faction has a Special Ability

The game is played using a standard chess board or other 8x8 grid, a standard deck of playing cards, six-sided dice, and a set of stackable tokens of a unique color for each player.

The object of the game is to eliminate all of the opposing Agents.
categories: Fighting, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Science Fiction

name: Matrix Replay
description:
“The Matrix: Movie theme. Card game for 2 players. One player is the Humans. The other player is the Machines.”

Each player uses a unique deck. Both decks include Character and Event Cards. In addition, the Human Deck contains Mission Cards. The Mission Cards are assigned a Mission Point value ranging from two to five.

“Objective: The Human player wins if he accumulates 20 Mission Points. (Neo hacks the Mainframe & makes a truce with the Machines). The Computer player can win in 3 ways: 1. Kill Neo, 2. Destroy the Nebuchadnezzer with Extermination Units, 3. Destroy Zion with Robot Army (Accumulate 20 Time Counters)”
categories: Card Game, Fighting, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Science Fiction

name: Melee
description: A card game of medieval combat between individual warriors. For two or more players. The cards represent weapons, weapons that can parry, basic attacks, opportunity attacks, shields, armor, and defenses. A player whose warrior receives twenty or more damage points is knocked out of the game. The last player remaining is the winner.

name: Mighty Magics
description:
“Fantasy Card Game for 2 or more players. Each player controls a Magical Kingdom at war with all the others.”

“Deck: Players share a common deck. The deck has 3 types of cards mixed in: Strongholds, Hordes, and Mighty Magics.”

“Stronghold Cards: These represent gains in territory. The card will have a Name, Force Value, Notes, and Recruitment Cost. Players can only defend with Strongholds. Strongholds are used to secure victory.”

“Horde Cards: These represent creatures, armies, monsters, heroes, and mages at your disposal. The card will have a Name, Force Value, and Recruitment Cost. Players can attack and defend with Hordes.”

“Mighty Magics: These cards will have a Name, Recruitment Cost, and special instructions.”

“Victory Conditions: The first player to begin his turn with 15 or more Force worth of Strongholds wins.”

name: Mission Improbable
description:
“Espionage card game for 2-6 players. Players try to complete missions with their agents.”

The game uses a custom deck of cards of eight different types. The cards and their general usage is as follows: Agents (able to go on missions), Missions (must be completed to win), Locations, Obstacles (must be overcome for a mission to be completed), Experience (permanently improve an agent’s capabilities), Equipment, Contacts (temporarily improve an agent’s capabilities), Events (affect game play in a variety of ways).

“Alignment: Each player decides whether their organization is good or bad. In a two player game, players must be of opposite alignments.”

“Nemesis: Each player picks one opponent to be their nemesis. The nemesis must be of the opposite alignment.”

“Object: At the end of the game, the player with the most mission points wins.”

name: Mogo
description:
“Fantasy version of Go. (Mogo = Monster Go) For 2 (or more) players.”

The game is played on a 10x10 grid using counters to represent Units, Locales, Relics, Enchantments, Sorceries, and Modifiers.

There are three ways to win the game. Getting seven counters in a row is a Tactical Victory. Capturing twenty or more enemy counters is a Logistical Victory. If the board is filled up, whoever controls the most counters earns a Strategic Victory.

name: Museum of Fine Arts
description:
“Card game for 2-6 players. Art Museum Theme. Each player controls their own Museum of Fine Arts. Players compete to acquire the most and best Art collections. The player to score the most points at the end of the game wins.”

The game is played using two custom decks of cards -- the Revenue Deck and the Collection Deck.

The Revenue Deck is composed of sixty cards in six suits reflecting different sources of revenue: Endowments, General Revenue, Restricted Gifts, Government Funding, Memberships, and Grants. These cards are used to bid on Collections in the Bidding Phase.

The Collection Deck is composed of seven suits reflecting different collections of artwork: Ancient, Classical, Early Western, Non-Western, Late Western, Modern, and Contemporary.

name: Myth Dimensions
description:
“Board & Card Game for 2+ players. Based on the Myth series of books by Robert Asprin. The series takes place in a humorous fantasy universe of Dimension-hopping Demons, Magicians & Con-Artists.”

The players represent main characters from the series: Isstvan, Garkin, Massha, Frumple, Diz-Ne, or Aahz & Skeeve. The characters have special abilities and limitations. Each character is rated for Guile, Savvy, Fight, and Magic. The players travel around a circular board, visiting bazaars, scamming the locals, and facing missions.

“Victory: The first player to accumulate 25 Reputation Points is the winner.”

name: Naruto Ninjutsu
description:
"Card game for 2 players. Naruto Theme: A Combat between 2 Ninjas." Inspired by the Japanese cartoon character Naruto.

The players choose to play one of eight different characters:
Naruto, Susuke, Sakura, Kakashi, Zabuza, Haku, Rock Lee, and Garaa. Thirteen statistics are given for each character: Rank, Sex, Village, Attack, Defense, Stamina, Speed, Tactics, Skill, Convert, Taijutsu, Ninjutsu, and Equipment.

The object of the game is to reduce the opponent's Stamina to zero.
categories: Card Game, Fighting, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Newsprint
description:
"Card game for 2-4+ players. Players are reporters for rival newspapers."

Cards are played from a hand of ten to form news stories. Circulation points are awarded based on how many cards can be used to form the story - from one card (one circulation point) to ten (one hundred circulation points).

"The player with the most circulation points at the end of 5 turns wins."

name: Nose Goblins
description:
"Card game, about, you guessed it, nose picking."

The deck includes five types of cards: Pick, Booger, Special, Negate, and Bonus Point Modifier.

"Victory: The first player with a collection of 100 Magic Nose Goblin Points (MNGP) wins."

name: Orkworld Quest
description:
"Card & Dice game for 2-4 players. Based on the Orkworld RPG by John Wick. Each player controls a Tribe (Gathum) of Orks." Solo play rules are also included.

"Use Metal or plastic figures to represent your Population. 1 Figure = 1 Ork."

The game also uses a custom deck of cards composed of nine types of cards: Foe, Weapon, Armor, Tribal Item, Personal Item, Personal Modifier, Tribal Modifier, Battle Event, and Non-Battle Event.

The players attempt to build their tribes into effective fighting forces in order to defeat Foe cards played on the tribes by other players. Defeating a Foe card increases a Tribe's Fame Points.

In addition to taking casualties in battle, other circumstances will affect the population of the players' tribes. Each turn a hunting roll is made to determine whether conditions will result in any increase or decrease in population.

"Victory: The first player to accumulate 25 Fana (Fame) points and survive is the winner."

name: Paladin in Hell
description:
“You made a wrong turn & fell into the Abyss. Now you must fight your way out. Solo card game.”

The game uses two card decks – the Holy Deck and the Demon Deck. The Holy Deck contains the attack and defense cards that will be used by the player. The Demon Deck contains cards representing the demons that are attacking the player and the locations in Hell that the player is traveling through.

“Victory: You win if you defeat all the Demons in the Demon Deck. You lose if you are ever reduced to zero or less Life Points. Your final score is the number of Life points you have left.” The player starts the game with twenty Life Points.

name: Pantheons
description:
“Card game for 2 players. Each player is a Greater God trying to build up his pantheon.” The monsters, gods, and events appear to have been inspired by tales of mythology from various European countries.

The card deck includes seven types of cards: Gods, Armies, Heroes, Priests, Monsters, Miracles, and Temples. Tokens are used to keep track of Worshipers. The players use their armies, heroes, and monsters, and priests to attack the opposing forces and temples. These actions may also result in the elimination or conversion of opposing Worshipers.

The object of the game is to have seven or more God Cards in play on your side. God Cards are put into play by expending Faith Points. The Faith Points available to a player are determined each turn based on the number of Worshipers, Priests, and Temples controlled by the player.

name: Pawn Poker
description:
An abstract strategy game played on a large 5x5 grid. The game also requires a different colored pawn for each player and a standard deck of playing cards.

At the start of the game, the deck is shuffled and a card is placed on each of the twenty-five spaces on the board. The players then select their starting corners and place their pawns.

As the players take turns moving their pawns, they get to keep the card (if any) from the space that the pawn was moved from. The game ends when all of the cards have been collected.

The object of the game is to make the best five card Poker hand from the playing cards collected by the player.

name: Pawnshop
description:
"Card & dice game for 2+ players. Each player is a pawnshop owner."

The custom card deck used in the game contains two types of cards - Item Cards and Event Cards. Each Item Card has three values on it: Pawn, Interest Fee, and Sell. The Event Cards reflect random events that help or hinder the players.

"Winning: The first player to accumulate $10,000 is the winner."

The designer notes: "I used to work in a pawnshop. Saw some crazy stuff."

name: Pirate War
description:
"Players control Pirate ships in search of plunder & adventure. The first player to accumulate 7 Treasures and have them stored in their home port is the winner."

The units in the game are based on the fleets from the Warhammer naval game Man O' War. The players can control pirate ships from the Empire, Brettonian, Elf, Dwarf, Orc, or Chaos fleets.

name: Pirates Backgammon
description:
A pirate themed strategy game played on a Backgammon board. The four quadrants of the board are referred to as Outer Sea (points 1-6), Great Sea (points 7-12), Middle Sea (points 13 -18), and Inner Sea (points 19-24).

There are three types of pieces used in the game – Pirates, Merchants, and Man-o-Wars. In addition, tokens are used to represent Gold Coins.

The Pirate piece is used to collect Gold Coins. While gold is in the Pirate ship it is subject to being lost or plundered. When a player bears gold off the board, it is placed in the player’s Treasure Chest where it is safe.

“The first player to accumulate 25 Gold Coins in his Treasure Chest is the winner.”
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement

name: Pirates Own Game
description:
A card game of pirate plunder and adventure for two or more players. The object of the game is to be the first player to have a Buried Treasure pile worth twenty Gold or more.

The game is played with three decks of cards: Pirates Own Deck, Event Deck, and Plunder Deck.

The Pirates Own Deck includes three types of cards related to the pirate forces: Captains, Ships, and Crew. The Plunder Deck includes two types of cards: Treasures (having a Gold value) and Objects (provide an advantage when carried on a ship). The cards in the Event Deck are random events that can help or hinder players.
categories: Card Game, Fantasy, Fighting, Nautical, Pirates

name: Plane Wars
description:
“Card game for 2+ players. Raid/Skirmish level Fantasy combat. Each deck represents one of the races found in the Outer (or Inner) Planes of the AD&D Universe. Currently available decks include: Githyanki, Githzerai, Mind Flayer, Beholder, Modron, Slaadi, Daemon, Deva.”

“Each player uses his own Primary and Secondary deck. Each deck is specific to a single race. Players also share a common Spell Deck & Psionics Deck.” Units depicted on the cards represent Monsters, Fighters, and Wizards.

“Victory: Defeat a Player by reducing him to zero Morale points.” Each player starts with fifty Morale points.
categories: Card Game, Fantasy, Fighting, Print & Play

name: Plantation Master
description: A card based game in which each player controls a plantation in Early America. The players compete to establish the biggest cotton, tobacco, sugar, rice, and indigo fields. The game is driven by a custom deck of cards. There are two types of cards in the deck: Events and Permanents. Permanents include Cash Crop Fields, Buildings, and Slave Quarters. Slave Quarters are required to support fields and buildings.

name: Power Rangers
description:
A card game inspired by the first two seasons of the Power Rangers television series.

One player gets a Ranger Deck, the other player gets a "Bad Guy Deck." To play a game based on season one, the respective players use the Mighty Morphin Power Ranger Deck and the Rita Repulsa Deck. For season two, the White Ranger Deck and Lord Zed Decks are used.

The first player to win five hands wins the game.
categories: Card Game, Fighting, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Progression
description:
"Math themed Card game for 2-4+ players."

"The Deck: Cards are numbered zero to nine (0-9). There are 6 copies of each card. The Deck is composed of 60 cards."

The object of the game is to play a progression of three related numbers from a hand of eight cards. Seven types of progressions are acceptable: Basic, Algebraic, Prime, Exponential, Pythagorean, Fibonacci, and Geometric.

"Winning: The first player to make 5 Progressions wins."

name: Psionica
description:
“Players are Psionic warriors trying to destroy each others minds and bodies. 2+ player card game.”

The game uses a custom deck of over 60 cards. The cards are divided into the following types: ESP, Mental Attack, Physical Attack, Special Mental Attack, Incapacitating Attack, Power, Regeneration, Defense, Mental Defense, and Physical Defense.

“Setup: Each player starts with 20 Physical points and 20 Mental points. Each player starts with 3 cards. Determine turn order by rolling high on 1D6. The first player to go must discard a card.”

“Object: Reduce your opponent to 0 Physical or Mental points.”

name: Psychobabble
description:
"Players are Therapists trying to cure their patients and themselves."

The game is played on a square track with 13 spaces on a side. Each player has a set of pawns that move around the board, one of which represents the player's therapist and the rest of which represent the player's patients. A player can have a maximum of five patients at one time. The player attempts to cure patients by reducing the Neurosis Points score for each patient to zero.

The game ends after exactly one hour.

"Winning: The player with the most Total Victory Points (VP) wins. Gain 10 VP for each patient you cure. Lose 10 VP for each patient you fail."

name: Psych Ward
description:
“Card game for 2 or more players. Players are medical professionals working in a hospital psych ward. Match drugs to diagnoses to score points.”

“The Decks: Players share two common decks: The Patient Deck, and the Treatment Deck.” Each of the 33 cards in the Patient Deck represents a patient. A Patient Card describes the patient’s diagnosis and treatment requirements.

The Treatment Deck contains two types of cards – Drug Cards and Contraindication Cards. The Drug Cards, a few of which describe “non-pharmacological treatment options”, are used to treat patients. “Contraindication cards represent ADR’s (Adverse Drug Reactions), Side effects, Co-morbid disease states, Drug interactions, Kinetics, Dynamics, Dosing, and Administration errors that would result in therapeutic failure.” The Contraindication Cards are used to negate Drug Cards played by opposing players.

“Setup: Each player starts with a hand of 5 random Treatment cards. Determine Turn order (the player with the longest name goes first).”

“Objective: The game ends when all patients have been successfully treated. The player, at the end of the game, with the most patients in his file is the winner.” A Patient Card is placed in a player’s file when the player completes the treatment of the patient.

name: Quarks
description:
"Card game for 2 + players. Quantum Particle Physics Theme."

The game uses a custom card deck containing seven types of cards: Quarks, Carrier Particles, Baryons, Mesons, Leptons, Score Cards, and Special Cards.

The object of the game is to play various scoring combinations of cards. The winner is the first player to accumulate ten points.

name: Quest for the Old Ones
description:
“Card game based on the Elf Quest Universe.”

Each player controls a tribe of elves, choosing from one of four types: Wolf Riders, Sun Folk, Blue Mountain Gliders, or Go-Backs. Tribes may include Character Members (represented by cards) and non-character members (represented by tokens). Each member of a tribe represents one Elf and, if it has one, its Bond Beast.

The custom card deck used in the game contains the following types of cards: Character, Land, Weapon Aid, Magic Aid, Ally Aid, Encounter, Food, and Event Cards.

“To win you must awaken the Old one. To do this you must travel a distance of 15 land cards. The last land you place must be a Mountain or Tundra (The Frozen Mountains). The last land you place is considered to be an entrance to the ‘Palace’.” Once there, the player must defeat the Guardian Trolls. The first player to do so wins the game.

name: Quickie Figs
description:
“Very simple Miniatures rules. Ranges, distances, and movement abstracted. No record keeping, charts, or tables. Games resolved in under 10 minutes. These rules are based on Sci-Fi figures, but other types will work just as well.”

A miniatures game to be played with ten to twenty figures, or more. The players divide the figures into two opposing forces “based on aesthetic reasons.” Combat is resolved starting with weapons that can attack at extreme range, followed in succession by long range attacks, medium range attacks, short range attacks, and finally hand-to-hand attacks. A single six-sided die roll is used to resolve combat.

name: Quidditch Cup
description:
“Card game for 2 players. Players are each in control of opposing Quidditch teams.” Based on the magical sport from the world of Harry Potter.

In each Action Phase, the players make three piles of face-down cards which are later revealed simultaneously: the Bludger-Beater Pile, Quaffle-Chaser Pile, and Snitch-Seeker Pile.

To win the game, a player must have a specified force value in the Snitch-Seeker Pile, together with at least one Snitch and one Seeker Card. This causes the player to score 150 points and the game is over.
categories: Card Game, Fantasy, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Novel-based, Sports

name: Raging Gun Battle
description:
“Each player controls one character in a Raging Gun Battle.” The object of the game is to reduce all of your opponents to zero Hit Points.

The players pick one of the following “Character Archetypes”: Bruiser, Thug, Fem Fatale, Secret Agent, Mercenary, Black Ops Specialist, Hard-Boiled Cop, Enforcer, Hit-man, Rookie Cop, Assassin, Crime Boss, Gangster, Gun Nut, etc.

Each Character starts with ten Hit Points, one Gun Card, and two rolls on the Ability table. The abilities a character may have are: Tough, Danger Sense, Armed to the Teeth, Smart, Fast, Stealth, Resourceful, Lucky, Tactics, and Sharpshooter.

The game is played using a custom deck of cards. There are seven types of cards in the deck: Gun, Damage, Bullets, Card play, Attack Advantage, Negate Attack, and Extra Attack.

name: Ragnarok
description:
"The last epic battle in Norse mythology of Good against Evil."

The forces of the Good Aesir and Vanir battle against the Evil Giants. In addition to ten Norse Gods, the forces of Good are supported by Valkyries, Einheriar, Dwarves, and Elves. The forces of Evil are supported by Undead Hordes, Stone Giants, Storm Giants, Fire Giants, and Frost Giants. Each unit is rated for movement, strength, range, and any special abilities.

The game is played on a hex mapsheet depicting Asgard. The invading Giants line up on one side of the map. The forces of Good begin clustered around Valhalla. The object of the game is to destroy all opposing units.

name: Ravenloft Quest
description:
“Each player controls a party of Heroes traveling through the Northern Core of Ravenloft, the Demi-Plane of Dread.”

The game is played on a track ninety spaces long. The start and end spaces are Mist spaces, the other spaces are Domain spaces. Each named Domain is eight spaces long. There are eleven Domains, each of which has its own encounter table.

“The first player whose party (pawn) reaches the end space wins. You lose if all of your Heroes are killed.”

This is a fan-made game available at http://www.angelfire.com/games2/warpspawn/RLQ.html

name: Redwall
description:
“Two Player Card Game. Based on the Book ‘Redwall’ by Brian Jacques”

“One Player represents Matthias the Mouse and the Defenders of Redwall Abbey. The other Player represents Cluny the Scourge and his Army of Rats.”

“Victory: Whichever player wins the Final Battle wins the game. The Final Battle is hand #13. If the Cluny player wins 3 hands in a row, the next hand is automatically the Final Battle.”
categories: Animals, Card Game, Fantasy, Medieval, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Novel-based

name: Renaissance Fair
description:
"Get the most out of your trip to the Renaissance festival. Board game for 2+ players."

The game is played on an 85 space track. Each space is named for an event, activity, or exhibition. Examples include Glass Blower, Throwing Axes, Medieval Beer, Henna Tattoos, and Tarot Reader. Tokens are gained by landing on certain spaces.

The object of the game is to be the first player to get five of each type of Token: Craft, Game, Food, Acting, Music, and Education.

name: Rules of Order
description:
“Card game for 2+ players. Representation of a parliamentary debate. Based on Robert’s Rules of Order. Players compete to capture the Floor, which enables them to use up (gain) the most Time.”

“Victory: The player with the most Time Chips at the end of the game wins.”

name: Rum Runner
description:
“2-Player Pirate Strategy War Game. One player plays the rum runners. The other player plays the interceptors (rival pirates).”

The game is played on a chess board or other 8x8 grid. There are seven types of units in the game: Swashbucklers, Swordsman, Slashers, Rum Runners, Musketeers, Pirates, and Mercenaries. The Rum Runner player has three Rum Runners, three Pirates, two Musketeers, and two Mercenaries. The Interceptor player has six Swordsmen, three Slashers, and one Swashbuckler. The Rum Runner player must get one Rum Runner to the opposite side of the board to win. The Interceptor must kill all of the Rum Rummer units.

The designer notes: “Game was originally designed to be played with the 37 piece plastic ‘Pirates on the High Seas’ set from D&D Distributing Inc. but is suitable for use with paper tiles.”

name: Sailor Moon
description:
"Help Sailor Moon & the Sailor Scouts protect Earth from the Negaverse and the Negamoon."

Each player has a custom deck of sixty cards. One player uses the Space Scouts Deck, the other player controls the Nega Deck. Alternate sets of cards for the Nega Deck are used to reflect the events of season one (Negaverse) and season two (Negamoon).

The first player to win three hands wins the game.
categories: Card Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Science Fiction

name: Shot, Shell & Grape
description:
"Two player Card game depicting Napoleonic era warfare."

The game uses two card decks, the Battalion Deck and the Tactics Deck. The Tactics deck is composed of maneuvers, formations, weapons, incidents, and terrain types. The Battalion Deck consists of thirty three types of military units (Infantry, Cavalry, and Artillery).

Cards are played on the table in battlefield positions representing the Left Flank, Left Center, Center, Right Center, and Right Flank positions. The first player to be routed from three of the five forward positions loses the game.

These rules served as the basis for the game Ready Aim Fire.

name: Sin City
description:
“Card game based on the Frank Miller Comic Sin City. 2+ Players.”

The game uses a custom deck composed of Event Cards and seven types of Character Cards: Event, Criminal, Agent, Psychopath, Hero, Victim, and Crime Boss. Each Character has a Fight rating and a Sin rating.

The players draw Character cards, place them into play, and use them to hunt down and kill the Characters of the opposing players. Sin Points are earned by killing Characters. The amount received depends on the types of Characters involved.

“Victory: The first player to accumulate 100 Sin Points is the winner.”
categories: Card Game, Fighting, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Sleep
description:
“Card Game 2+ players. Players are trying to see who can get the best nights rest.”

Each player uses a Sleep Track marked with five stages ranging from Awake (stage 0) to Slow Wave Sleep (stage 4) to show which Sleep Stage the player is on. The players play Sleep Cards to advance to deeper levels of sleep. Wake Cards are played on an opponent to reduce the opponent’s Sleep Stage. At the end of each turn, a player gains a number of Sleep Tokens equal to the player’s current Sleep Stage.

“The game lasts 16 turns. Each turn represents Half an Hour. This would correspond to a full nights sleep of 8 hours.” The winner is the player with the most Sleep Tokens at the end of the game.

name: Scooby-Doo Mystery Game
description:
“Solve Mysteries with Scooby Doo & the gang of Mystery Inc. Card game for 2+ players.”

The players attempt to solve Mysteries by playing melds. A Mystery is solved by playing a meld containing one of each of the following types of cards: Scooby, Shaggy, Fred, Velma, Daphne, Villain, and Location.

“Winning: The first player to solve 3 Mysteries is the winner.”
categories: Card Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Murder/Mystery

name: Space Blast
description:
“Backgammon variant on a circular board with cards and a sci-fi theme. One player is the Terran Defense Force. The other player is the Evil Empire.”

The board is a circular track divided into twenty-eight spaces. There are four planet spaces equally spaced around the board. Each side has fifteen units marked with a force value from one to five. Cards can modify combat or provide a variety of other effects. The first player to occupy all four planet spaces is the winner.

name: Space Program
description:
“Card game for 2+ players. Each player represents a National Space Program. Players acquire technologies, perform Missions, and develop Space Industries.”

The deck contains eight types of cards: Projects, Missions, Industry, Lift Capability, Near Earth, Zero-G Industries, Stellar Transport, and Disasters. Each type of card has a Prestige Point value.

Each turn represents a decade. The game ends when the players have gone through the deck twice. The player with the most Prestige Points at the end of the game wins.

name: Space Station Alpha
description:
“Bidding & Placement Game. Each player represents a space agency: NASA, European Union, Russia, Japan, etc. Players are working together to build the ISS (International Space Station). Players add Modules and score points.”

The game is played on a chess board or other 8x8 grid. The center four spaces of the board represent the Core Command and Control Module of the space station.

The space station is to be constructed out of sixty Modules represented by cardboard counters. There are four each of fifteen different types of Modules in the counter mix. Each player has a set of forty markers in a unique color that are used to show ownership of Modules placed on the space station. Victory points are earned based on various factors related to the placement and location of Modules.

“Objective: The game ends at the end of the turn when all 60 modules have been placed. The player with the most victory points at the end of the game wins.”

name: Pink Pebbles
description:
From the box:

A game about how money began.

Pink Pebbles takes players back to a world without money. Players begin as primitive farmers, trying to produce everything they need.

But there's an entrepreneur in every crowd - and some of the players soon begin to barter, trying to swap extra things they've made. The successful players become specialists and store owners. That's where the pink pebbles come in. Any good store needs some form of money....

The player who has the most pink pebbles with at least two stores at the end of the game wins.

name: Trucopoly
description:
From the publisher:

Its all about the trucking business, You know those BIG TRUCKS that are always flying down the road. The object of the game is, who ever builds a fleet of ten trucks first wins. As you build your fleet of trucks, you contend with WEIGH STATIONS, DOT CHECKS, IRS, FUEL TAX, ROAD TAX, SHIPPERS, BROKERS TRUCK STOPS AND THE LIST GOES ON. Unlike some game's where every one gets tired and quits, this game is fast, fun and keeps you thinking. Someone will build a fleet of trucks and win the game in a fair amount of time. If you are wondering, yes there are forty trucks in the game to support up to 4 players.

name: The War in Heaven
description:
"A long time ago, in a Universe far, far away, a race who had tyrannically ruled time and space in their Universe had to face the premature end of their Continuum. The end of the Universe was prompted by a powerful being known as Dionysus. Dionysus and some of his comrades escaped into the next Universe, which was an Antiverse to their original home. That Antiverse is our own present universe."

"The Virtuous Dionysus, his comrades from the previous Universe and righteous Empire at the end of time strive to protect our Universe from the invasion of the previous Time/ Space Continuum’s natives. Led by the mysterious Time’s Champion, the Exousia and Arche are struggling to establish a beachhead in our Universe (their Antiverse) from which they can write themselves into our Time Continuum’s history. Only Dionysus, the Empress, Archaggelos, Malak’s, and Clade, can prevent the self proclaimed Time’s Champion, the Imperiatrix, the Exousia, Arche and Shed from conquering our Time/ Space Continuum."

One player assumes the role of Dionysus, while the other plays Time’s Champion. Each player has a set of non-collectible cards to be played using the rules from the Magic: The Gathering.

name: The Great Traveling Circus Game
description:
"Each player is the owner of a traveling circus."

A web published game for which you can make your own components, or you can use the board, pawns, money, houses, and hotels from a Monopoly set.

A custom deck of Act Cards will need to be created. Each card represents a carnival or circus act. There are four types of acts: acrobats, clowns, animals, and freaks. An Act Card is drawn any time a player lands on one of the spaces that requires any type of card to be drawn. The Monopoly cards are not used.

The game ends when the last card is drawn from the Act Deck. The player with the most money at the end of the game wins.

name: Volley
description:
“Two-player card game of Napoleonic Warfare."

Each player starts with 100 points of troops. The object of the game is to reduce the opponent's troop total to zero. Troop casualties are inflicted by playing melds during the Attack Phase.

The players share a common deck. The deck contains ten suits: Infantry Units, Infantry Weapons, Cavalry Units, Cavalry Weapons, Artillery Units, Artillery Weapons, Leaders, Strategy, Morale, and Defense.

A simplified version of Fusillade.
categories: Card Game, Fighting, Napoleonic, Print & Play

name: Super League
description:
"Titanic Struggle between Rival Super Hero/Villain Teams."

The game uses two decks of cards - the Recruit Deck and the Action Deck. The Recruit Deck contains Heroes/Villains, Minions, Aids, Plots, and Upgrades Cards. The Action Deck contains Events and Battle Cards. Six-sided dice are also required for play.

"Victory: You win if all Heroes/Minions of the opposing Team are neutralized."

name: Stargate Missions
description:
"Dice & Card game for 2+ players. Based on the Stargate Universe." The game uses three card decks: Personnel, Missions, and Events.

The Personnel Deck is composed of the characters you control. There are two types of Personnel: Main Characters and Support Personnel. When teamed up, Support Personnel are always lost or killed before Main Characters. Personnel have stats in two characteristics, Brains and Combat, and possess one or more of the following skills: Science, Medical, Communication, and Lore.

The Game ends when there are no cards left to draw from the Mission Deck. The player with the highest Victory Score wins the game. The Victory Score is based on the total points of all Missions completed and the number of Personnel that were lost or killed.
categories: Card Game, Exploration, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Science Fiction

name: Noah's Ark Animal Match
description:
Noah's Ark Animal Match Game

(c)1990 Jewish Educational Toys

"Help Noah gather all the animals into the Ark!"

Players match picture cards to the animals shown on the Ark gameboard. Includes a colorful board, 4 plastic tokens, 25 animal cards, and rules.

Designed for Ages 4 - 10 with no reading required.

name: ling-whist
description:
"The learn a language game.
Card game excitement while learning to speak Spanish/French."

Contents:
Phrase Book, Rules
120 Ling-Whist playing cards with letters and pronunciations.

Seven cards are dealt to each player, and a phrase is selected from the phrase book. During a turn a player draws a card and either discards a card or plays one to his current word. The word must be from the phrase chosen; it must be spelled in correct order, but the words themselves can be done in any order. The game ends when someone completes the sentence or the deck runs out, and players score:

for each player, 5 points for each completed word
for the player with the fewest points in hand, the difference between the opponent's hand and theirs
for winning, 25 points
plus the points on all the cards in the sentence
plus the points on incomplete words by the others
all doubled if the opponents did not complete a word, tripled if they didn't get a letter down



300 points wins the game.

Language practice comes in by reciting the chosen phrase, saying the letter's name when playing its card (e.g. 'HO-tah', not 'jay'), and reciting the phrase again when you repeat it.

name: Mjollnir
description:
The game of Mjollnir is named after the Norse God Thor's
mighty hammer which he could throw at an enemy and it
would always return to his hand after smashing his opponent.
Variations of these bluffing dice games were played all over
Scandinavia and were a fun way to pass the time around the
fire pit of a Viking long house during the long winter nights.

Mjollnir is a pretty easy game to learn and comes with
a game rules parchment. Besides playing Mjollnir, you can
use the dice and "shaker" box to play many other popular
dice games because each die is marked from 1 to 6 but with
our unique symbols such as Odin One-Eye or Freya's Tears

Each Mjollnir Game comes with a pair of Custom Dice
a dozen glass "gems" which are enough to start off four players
a complete "Rules" parchment and an attractively decorated
"Shaker" box that doubles as a storage container for your
dice and gems. The box is decorated using Pyrography or
wood burning which was a common technique in the
age of the Vikings.

name: Turn Over
description: Turn-Over is a game where you place one of the "Turn-Overs" which is an aluminum capsules with metal ball bearings on the board and you shift the board around and try to score points by having them fall into a holes that are worth different amounts of points.

name: Sword & Shield
description:
A rulebook for fantasy combat at various scales using miniature figures.

"Sword and Shield is for individual combat in the world of Acquitaine, and deals with realistic combat (jousts, tourneys, trial by combat and actual melee combat) as well as some of the fantastic denizens of Acquitaine."

"Concept based upon the novel, Shadowstalker, and stories of Eril Shadowstalker and Windsinger."

The rules cover individual combat, mass combat, jousting, sieges and siege equipment.

name: La Legion Etrangere
description:
A set of miniatures rules for gaming battles involving the French Foreign Legion, 1850-1930.

"This is a set of miniatures and role-playing rules, and as such has two separate combat systems. Although these systems are separate in the functions they fulfill, they are integrated in the sense that it allows an individual to take part in a larger action."

One of the combat systems governs "large scale battles", which use four figures to a stand for legionnaires and five to six figures to a stand for "native and rabble" units. The large scale battle system includes rules for ranged fire, melee fire, machine guns, and artillery.

The game includes two hex maps. One shows the layout of an Algerian village and the other is a map of a Foreign Legion fort.

name: United States
description:
"Educational Geography card game. Subject: The United States of America." For two or more players, with variant scoring rules for solo play.

The game uses a deck of fifty cards, each of which names one of the the U.S. states. The players are seeking to play melds of three or more cards consisting of states which are all adjacent to each other or which form a chain of adjacent states.

The winner is the player who has played the most state cards. Variant rules are provided for easier games and other educational exercises suitable for use with the cards.

name: Politrix
description:
"All the excitement and drama of the Presidential Campaign is captured in this unique new game for the 80's. Politrix combines the skill and strategy of Presidential Politics with humor & fun!! Race against opposition as you raise funds, buy votes, and form party tickets on the way to becoming President of the United States."

Basic roll-and-move with three circular tracks: fundraising, campaigning, and the election. The "unique" aspect of the game is that when players move into the middle (campaigning) track they must declare a political party (Democan or Republicrat) and only one player of each party may advance to the inner (election) as that party's nominee.

The game comes with: a board, 6 plastic tokens, two-page rules, 2 six-sided dice, scorepad, two sets of ballots (33 Democan & 33 Republicrat, 6 @ 50 votes & 27 @ 100 votes each), two event decks (25 "Campaign Strategy" cards and 40 "Between the Headlines" cards), paper money, and a "33rpm recording vital to your campaign" with strategy hints.

name: Lingo Foly's
description:
A language trivia game for 1 to 4 teams (min 1 player per team) to recognize English, German, French, and Spanish phrases.

Game is in French.
mechanics: Open Drafting, Roll / Spin and Move

name: C-TEC-OPOLY
description: C-TEC-OPOLY A monopoly game created for the C-TEC Corporation, a telecommunications company. Spaces shown on the board include the Mercer County (NJ) Airport, C-TEC Corporate Headquarters, MEGACABLE, Residential Communications Network, etc.

name: Wildfire
description:
WILDFIRE is a two move role-playing game that acquaints players with the problems associated with the spread of nuclear weapons and some of the solutions to these problems. The basic WILDFIRE game is designed to be played either in two 45-minute sessions of one move each or in a single 90-minute session with a short break between moves. A short introductory exercise is designed to be worked through in advance.

The game has three separate parts- an introductory exercise and two "moves". The introductory exercise covers the fundamentals of the problem and some basic facts (like who has nuclear arsenals today) and gets players thinking about the overall issue. The first move is a crisis control exercise in which players take on the roles of top officials in five nations that are wrestling with a future nuclear crisis involving India and Pakistan. The second and final move is a post-crisis negotiation exercise in which players seek a long-term solution to the conflict between India and Pakistan,
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Role Playing, Simulation, Team-Based Game
publishers: Roosevelt Center for American Policy Studies

name: The Big Board
description:
Released toward the end of the Great Depression in 1937, The Big Board, like many games released during this time frame, reflects an America, and the world, pulling itself out of economic chaos. The lure of trading large sums of cash with the possibility of striking it rich ran deep in the collective unconscious across the globe.

The box includes 835 shares of stock in each of nine different corporations with the following denominations/counts: 1/10, 5/5, 10/5, 50/5, 100/5. This is at odds with the instructions which call for 435 shares. It also includes approximately $110,000 in paper money in the following denominations: $5, $10, $20, $50, $100, $1,000 and $5,000. Again this is at odds with the instructions which call for $147,600. Included is one pair of standard dice, a dice cup, 9 wooden Price markers, and one large board marking the rising stock prices.

The Big Board “represents the quotation board as used in a broker’s office”, and attempts to “represent in a realistic manner the fluctuation of stocks, as on the New York Stock Exchange.” Nine stocks are available for trading. Each player starts with $5,000.00. One player is selected as the supervisor of the treasury and stock certificates. The instructions suggest that this player throws the dice and moves the price quotation markers, but is “not the banker and does not participate in the profits or losses of the BIG BOARD.”, effectively removing the player from the game. For those who don’t wish to be left out of the game, an easy house rule could fix this by allowing one person to be banker and perhaps shifting the throw of the dice from player to player.

The game begins with the price markers on each of the stock spaces marked PAR. The market is now open and all players may purchase one or more shares of as many stocks as they wish. The dice are then rolled for the first stock, with the operator moving the marker upward the matching number of spaces rolled. If the marker lands on a value space, the price is set, if it lands on a “Down To” space, it is moved to the corresponding lower value and the price is set there. Players may now buy or sell values of this stock. These phases are continued for each stock, with the dice returning to the first stock when the others have been set. During intervals, transactions can occur at the current price of any stock.

The game can end in several ways: at a set time determined by all players at the start of the game (suggested by the game designers as a more realistic simulation of stock activity from day to day), or when 1 player has lost all money or the treasury is exhausted, or even when 1 player has made a “certain amount of money over and above that which he started with”.
mechanics: Commodity Speculation, Dice Rolling, Simulation, Stock Holding

name: Spin and Spell Word Making Game
description: Spin the dial! Collect letters! See who can make the most words!

name: Wild Jacks
description: A Pente variant in which a hand of cards determines where you can place chips. Object is to get 2 lines of 5 on the board.

name: Last Step Game
description:
A simple abstract NIM game on a 5x5 board. Players start by alternately placing the shared pieces on the board, and then alternately moving the pieces E, SE, S, or SW. Last player to move loses.

Includes dozens of variants for pieces with different movement rules, win conditions, and a larger board on the flip side.

name: Comprendo!
description:
Now there's an easy way for all the family to speak Spanish while having fun.

Going to Spain? Play Comprendo!® the board game, and you'll soon be getting by effortlessly in the language!

This fast and fun family game simulates a holiday in Spain.

You don't need to know any Spanish beforehand – but you do need your wits about you!

By speaking Spanish words and phrases you collect day trips. The first person to match these day trips to their original 'wish list' wins.

You don't need any Spanish to play. The questions in Comprendo!® are specially constructed with clues so that even complete beginners can answer them. All the Spanish has an intuitive pronunciation guide. Playing Comprendo!® is not like being in a classroom. There's no grammar or exercises. You pick the language up unconsciously, by hearing and speaking. It's a friendly, fast-moving family game, and making the odd mistake is all part of the fun!

-- http://www.comprendogame.com

name: Prezyun Breake
description:
Translated from the manual:

A prison. It's where the shit jerks who did too much are put.
A place where the rats who were either stupid or clumsy are kept separated from society until they cool down.
No one, no matter how crazy, wants to go there.
But there was one complete idiot who ended up in the special prison for violent maniacs.
...and that's you.

It's defended by a system that Alcatraz or Bastilles don't come near. A huge hell, finely constructed and full of patrols.
If you can get out of there, the next thing and you'll be able to break of out Hell itself.
Even so, this is your line:
"So what. I have to do it."
You have to, to save the guy on death roll, who was innocently judged.
Use your skill, your genius and your brains to the fullest.
What awaits you is unimportant. Your must save the man, get him out of there, think tactically, and use whatever tools you can get ahold of.
Got it? Good. Let's get going.

name: Tumble Logs
description:
From the box: "Stack your logs on the pile in 45 seconds without letting any of them tumble and you score!"

The game includes three dice, a 45-second sand timer, and wooden "logs" of three different sizes and colors. On a player's turn, they roll the three dice. The color and number of each die tells how many logs of each color must be added to the stack. The player has 45 seconds to add them without wrecking the stack or having any logs roll off.

name: TEE-RIVIA
description:
TEE-RIVIA

Golf Trivia Game

(c)1994 DSH Enterprises

"A game for those who love golf, its rich history and its colorful heroes."

Players compete as individuals or teams as they move around a game board representing an 18 hole golf course answering trivia questions about golfing.

Includes 1200 questions on 400 cards, 6 playing pieces, dice, rules, and board.

Ages 14 and up.

name: Seawolf: A Game of Submarine Combat
description:
The third game in the "Great Little Game Line" (#7003).
