Al Pha Bet: All are dealt 7 cards. In a turn, a player draws 1 from the draw or discard pile, lays down a word or passes, and discards down to 7 if needed. Each word scores 5 per black vowel (there must be at least 1 per word), plus 1 per colored letter if there are at least 2 of them and they're all the same color; all doubled if the word is a palindrome (spelling another word backwards). Game ends after the draw pile's gone and all pass; highest total wins.

Alpha: Deal 7 face up to each player. In a turn, a player draws 1 and makes a word or passes and discards down to 7. If a word is played, each other player in turn gets a chance to add cards from their hand to the played word to make a different word, without changing the order. The last to add to the word wins it. Words score 1 per letter, doubled if monochrome, doubled if a palindrome.

Beta: A solitaire game. Deal 6 cards out in a line, starting 6 columns. You may move individual cards to the top of bottom of another column, removing words as completed. When done moving, deal another card to the bottom of each column (or empty slot if a column is empty). Continue until the deck is gone, trying to eliminate the whole deck.

Capa: A bridge-like partnership trick-taking game. Players first bid the number of words to make, along with a color (not black). Highest bid gets his color as trump, and his partner is dummy. Player to his left leads first. All plays must follow suit if possible, unless black is led. If a word is made in the color led, the leader wins the trick; if a word is made in a different color or multiple colors, the one who added the last card to it wins; if no word is made the leader wins. If the contractors get as many words as bid, they score for all words won, else the opponents score for all the words they won; words are scored as in Alpha.

name: WhizORD
description:
WhizORD deck has 108 cards, each having a letter of the alphabet, and a value from 1-10, rarer letters being worth more. Rules for several games are included:

Poker-WhizORD: Like draw poker with 7 cards and one draw per hand. The player with the highest-scoring words adds it to his total. Alternate rules add chips and betting typical to poker, with up to 3 rounds of betting.

Soli-WhizORD: A solitaire game. Player deals himself 10 hands as if in Poker-WhizORD -- including one draw -- and scores their best word. The goal is 300 points.

Rummy-WhizORD: Players have 7-card hands, and in each turn they play and score a word or pass and discard any number of cards; then they draw back up to 7. Winner is the first to an agreed total.

Thirty-WhizORD: Players start with 7-card hands, and in their turn draw 1 and discard 1. The first player with a 30-point word in hand calls "Thirty!", lays it down and wins the hand. Play to an agreed number of hands or wins.

Hangman-WhizORD: Players each think of a word with the same number of letters, and pick their letters out of the deck, laying them out face down in the opponent's reading order. Take turns guessing letters, correct guesses being revealed, incorrect guesses being noted to avoid repeats. You may guess the word but if guessed wrong you lose; otherwise the first one to expose all the opponent's letters wins.

Match'Em-WhizORD: 12 or more matching pairs of letters are pulled from the deck, suffled and laid out on the table. Players reveal 2 cards in their turn, keeping matches, as in Concentration/Pelmanism.

Precitd-WhizORD: One card is revealed. Each player reveals another card in turn, but first predicts whether their card will precede or follow the first card. The player who predicted correctly, and has the letter closest to the first letter, captures all the cards; no one wins if a tie or a card matches the first one. At the end of the deck, the most cards captured wins.

name: Quackers! Hide and Seek Game
description:
From the box:

"Which of these silly ducks is hiding the secret egg? Just follow the quacking sound as the ducks spin ’round and ’round! But be sure to grab the right duck or you may end up with the rotten egg! Game includes all you need for up to 6 players; spinning nest measures 10".
publishers: Nilco S.A., Toys to Grow on

name: The Big Spin Game Show
description:
From the Box:

"A real live game show you can host right in your own home! The Big Spin game lets contestants answer intriguing questions in 4 key categories: math, science, language and the arts. Kids just spin the wheel to select a category and earn points for each correct answer. The 14 1/2" write & wipe game board lets you tally up points as you play, and the game cards each have 3 different questions that vary in difficulty so kids of all abilities can play! With 80 game cards and a dry-erase marker. "

name: Fact Finders! Dino Builders Game
description:
From the box:

"Kids piece these cool dinos together fact by fact! To play, kids answer fascinating questions about their favorite prehistoric reptiles, spin the spinner and collect plastic bones to build their own T-Rex or stegosaurus! You get 40 question cards, plus simple photo cards showing how to put the dinos together. T-Rex is 18 1/2".

name: Republican
description:
A word card game with a mild political theme. The deck has 52 letter cards, and 2 jokers which can stand for periods or apostrophes in contractions or abbreviations. (There is an elephant on the back of each card, and a donkey on the front of the jokers.) An extra deck is recommended if more than 3 play.

Players are dealt 10 cards, and the top of the draw is turned over to start the discard pile. In a turn a player draw one from either pile and discards one. If they think they have a winning hand they "call a vote", and everyone lays down their hands to score. The player with the highest-scoring hand adds its points, plus a 10-point bonus, to their total. Play to 150 points for the win.

One or more words can be formed from the hand when scoring, but the points favor longer words. Each word scores the "triangle number" of the number of letters it contains:
1 - 1
2 - 3
3 - 6
4 - 10
5 - 15
6 - 21
7 - 28
8 - 36
9 - 45
10 - 55

There are several possible bonuses: a player who can use all his hand to spell words may "vote his hand" (similar to going Gin), automatically winning the hand and getting a 20-point bonus. Spelling certain Reward Words:
WORK, THRIFT, PROFIT, YOU, WIN
earns double its point count. Spelling certain 10-letter Winning Words:
REPUBLICAN, PATRIOTISM, CAPITALISM, PRODUCTION
earns 150 points and wins the game outright.

name: Pocahontas Adventure VCR Game
description:
"The game you can play while you watch your 'Pocahontas' video!"

(c)1996

Players move around a colorful board as they watch the movie. When certain events occur during the film players take Canoe Cards or Grandmother Willow cards from the deck. These cards are used to help the players get to the finish line and win the game.

Includes board, spinner, cards, tokens, and a package of Nestle Quik!
categories: Children's Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Horrible Science Seriously Squishy Games
description:
A compendium of 4 games to accompany the Horrible Science collection of books. Contains:

- Spiders and twigs game: A straight roll and move with plastic bugs for counters.

- Spitting Cobra: Use the water pistol to try to hit the squishy eyeball.

- Archer Fish: Use the water pistol to try to hit the plastic bugs.

- Queen Bee!: A hex based draughts/checkers variant.

name: Echelon
description:
Echelon is a three-dimensional abstract strategy game in which two players build a structure while attempting to get five cubes of their own color in a row.

Starting with a black "starting cube", players alternate placing in one of two ways:

1) Playing three cubes in a row (as viewed from above), with at least one cube on top of a preexisting one, or;

2) Playing two cubes as above, but also removing an edge-adjacent cube from the structure.

The game also includes two "anchor cubes" of each color, which may not be removed from play by either player, as well as one "shift cube" for each, which may only be removed by the owning player.

Note: the front of the package claims the game is suitable for 2-4 players, but the interior of the rulebook reveals that doing so entails purchasing another set of cubes (they were apparently sold in two sets; one with red and blue cubes, and the other with green and purple).

name: Witch Dice
description:
Lion, Lisa, London – Who is quick at finding words with the letter being searched for?

A bewitching word game collection for 2-8 players ages Ages 7 and up.
categories: Children's Game, Fantasy, Real-time, Word Game

name: Tactical Football
description:
Early dice based football game. Has only 4 types of plays that may be run; Forward Pass, Line Buck, Trick Play and Kick.

Uses 7 custom dice, 4 for the offensive player 3 for the defense. After rolling you look up the result on a chart.

name: Oh the Wondrous Places You'll Go! Travel Card Game
description:
Start imagining your wondrous journey!

Tickle your travel bug with this deck of cards describing 51½ wondrous places you can go! Each card features stunning photography, unbelievable facts, surprising history, and brain-twisting trivia about a multitude of amazing destinations.

Easy to store and tote, Oh the Wondrous Places You'll Go! Game is the perfect family entertainment for road trips, air travel, a rainy day—or for any time you're craving a little excitement. From famous landmarks to hidden gems, a world of adventure awaits!

name: WUPS! Unabridged Edition
description:
From the box...

The Adult Jigsaw Grossword Puzzle Game

WUPS! is a game wherein some words of Anglo Saxon origin may be formed which are considered slang or vulgarisms. While it is the object of the game not to form such words, it frequently happens. These words may refer to body parts or body functions.

The game comprises a box containing a shelf with a round hole in it and a 36-piece jigsaw puzzle. The jigsaw puzzle has sixty four letter words on it in a crossword puzzle grid. Some of the words are repeats. The same sixty words are on each side of the puzzle and the puzzle is cut so that the words are divided in half. Many of the edge pieces may be interchanged and all of the interior pieces are interchangeable. The corner pieces are unique. As players take turns reassembling the puzzle with pieces chosen at random, some embarrassing words may be formed. The winner is the player who makes the fewest "naughty" words.
categories: Humor, Party Game, Puzzle, Word Game

name: Roll 'n Subtract
description:
The Game of Subtraction, Strategy and Fun!

Learn how to subtract numbers the Roll ’n Subtract fun way! It is easier than you think! Play with your friends while learning subtraction- challenge your friends while learning strategies.

Simply roll the dice, subtract the numbers, check your answer against the subtraction table, and start building a triangle. The real fun starts when you plan a strategy and capture your opponent’s playing pieces!

name: St炭dentinn
description: A single track game with 125 spaces, similar to The Game of Life, where start in childrens school and try to finish as college graduates the quickest. There are 25 special spaces that are similar to the Snake & Ladders game, where you can move forward or backwards.

name: Bild-A-Word
description:
A very early word card game. Its deck has 36 cards, all with letters except for two Blockade Cards, which just take up space in the hand without being usable. It also includes cardboard chits labeled "5 Points" or "10 Points"; some editions include a pocket dictionary. The rules describe five games:

Original Bild-A-Word: 5 cards each are dealt. In the first round, each player in turn lays 1-2 words of 2+ letters on the table, or adds letters to an existing word (rearranging if needed) to make a new word, or passes. From then on, a turn starts by drawing 1 card and ends with discarding 1 card; if the draw pile runs out, shuffle the discards to restock it. The hand ends when a player empties his hand, and he scores 5 points per cards held in others' hands -- the point chits are used to keep score. 250 points wins the game.

Bild-A-Word Triplets: Like the Original game, except that after the deal, 3 cards are placed in separate rows on the table. Players may not start new words, but only try to add to the existing rows to make new words. Letters may be rearranged within a row but not moved between rows.

Bild-A-Word Marathon: 8 cards are dealt to the table. In each turn, a player makes a word out of any 2 or more letters on the table. They may not repeat previous words, and have only 1 minute per turn. When a player is stumped they are out; the winner is the last player to come up with a word.

Bild-A-Word Wits: Like 5 card draw poker with words. Players start with 100 points worth of Point chits, and win on getting 300 points worth. Hands are ranked by the length of the words in them: 5 letters; 4; 3&2; 3; 2&2; 2. Ties are broken by the letters earliest in the alphabet.

Bild-A-Word Quinto: Like gin rummy. Players start with 5 cards, and in a turn draw 1 and discard 1. The first to make a 5-letter word from his hand calls "Quinto" and lays his hand down. All other players lay down their hands and make the longest word they can; the winner gets 5 point for each unused card. Game is 250.

name: AlphaBet
description:
Texas Hold-Em with words. The deck has 83 cards each with a letter and value of 1-8.

All start with an equal number of chips. There is a typical order: ante; deal 3 "hole" cards to each player; a round of betting; 2 "flop" cards face up in the middle; betting; 1 more face up (the "turn"); betting; 1 last card face up (the "river"); betting; the showdown. The players who haven't folded make their highest scoring word from their hole and the common cards; if a word has 6 letters, its value is doubled, if 7, it is tripled. Highest score wins the pot; if a tie, the pot is shared.

name: Prince Little's Marble Bowling Contest
description: Players aim at the targets and try to knock them off the target either by simply rolling the marble or by using the thumb as in other marble games. Highest score wins. Game comes with 2 long wooden sections and 6 characters that are hung on the frame and serve as targets.

name: Completly Veggie
description:
Fast little card and token game where you need to buy vegetable seeds at the market, grow them every turn and sell them for profit without the other players ruining it for you.
The player that manage his gold the better and get the most cash by the end of the year wins the game.

name: Astro
description: This is an astrological game, revolving around the twelve signs of the Zodiac. Based on the roll of a die, actions on the Astrocards and the player's purchases during the game, a personality description is finally constructed which fits each player. In addition the numbers that players purchase during the game decide the winner of the game.

name: tr叩sarv鱈kingaspili丹
description: A spoof game about the so called 'Financial Vikings' of Iceland. The board is only 14 spaces (including the starting space) and players roll two die to get to space 13. If the player doesn't get 13 on the roll, he moves from space to space until he ends up on the beginning space again. If the player gets 13 he's done the impossible and won the game.

name: Kreuzwortr辰tsel-Spiel
description:
The title means "Crossword Puzzle Game", and it matches that description very closely. [The rules were in German, but I believe I have the gist of it.]

The game is for two players or teams. There are 2 decks of 60 cards, one red and one blue. Each has 45 letters and 15 blocks -- which show a checkerboard but stand for the filled-in squares between the words in an actual crossword puzzle.

Each side shuffles their letter cards and draws a hand of 10 cards. The first player lays out a word from their hand horizontally, places a block card at either end of the word, and draws back up to 10. The opponent then places a word vertically, using one of the existing letters as part of it, also capping its end with block cards. Play continues in this manner, one side doing horizontal words, the other vertical, forming a typical crossword. Only one word can be done per turn. A word may be lengthened instead, the block being removed and replaced at the end of the longer word. If a player cannot play he passes.

The game ends when a side runs out of cards, or neither side can make a new word. The winner is the one with the most cards played.

name: Verbum Est
description:
A word card game, whose deck has 85 cards, each with a letter and its value.

In the basic game, a player's turn consists of turning over 3 letters face up in order, and naming as many words as they can that contain those 3 letters in that order. Example: with PAT, you could name sPAT, PArT, sePAraTe, etc. Then the score is the sum of the cards' values time the number of words stated. There is a maximum of 5 words, and a time limit is recommended for the turns. If the player thinks no word is possible he declares a Stymie, and if no one else can think of a word he gets 100 points; if someone can, she gets 50 points while the declarer loses 50. After the deck runs out, highest total wins.

There are several variations:

1. Juniors - For younger players, use 2 cards instead.

2. Sliders - use 2 cards, and only 5-letter words with both letters adjacent are allowed, one each of XXxxx, xXXxx, xxXXx, and xxxXX.

3. Twos - Use 2 cards, and think of any number of words (up to ten), of any length, with both letters adjacent.

4. Famous Names - Use 2 cards, and try to think of a famous name with those initials.

5. Initials - Use 2 cards, and think of a phrase, or two related words, the begin with those two letters. (E.g., with MD, Medical Doctor.)

6. Solitaire - use 3 cards, and find only 1 word per triple; try to find one for each triple dealt.

7. Charades - Use 2 cards, and act out a phrase starting with those two letters.

name: Nemcol
description:
This is a quasi-word game that is unique in several aspects: the words used are personal names; the cards stand only for vowels; everyone is working on the same word at once.

It has a 52-card deck, each of which has a vowel (AEIOU) or semi-vowel (WY), a number value, and a list of names that use that vowel. The 52nd card, though, is a Substitute card which can stand for any vowel.

Seven cards are dealt to each player. On his turn a player declares and spells a personal name, and then everyone must discard the vowels in that name. For example, if he says "Andrew", everyone in turn must discard an A card, then each must discard an E, then each must discard a W. Any player who cannot discard the current letter must draw from the draw pile, and discard it if it's the right letter, or keep it if not. The discard pile is reshuffled to replenish the draw pile, if needed.

A player goes out on playing his last card in hand, except that the caller cannot go out until the name he called is finished. When a hand is over, each player scores the sum of the cards still in hand. Play until someone reaches an agreed total, at which point the lowest total wins.

name: Pixie Play Tray
description:
This is a collection of three card games and a tray to play them in. The cards are square and of thick cardstock. The plastic tray has 3x3 playing area of recessed squares -- to allow stacking while preventing slippage ("great car fun") -- and a deeper square to the side for the draw pile.

Each game has its own small deck, and in each game players take turns drawing a card and playing it onto the 3x3 board.

1. Wiggle Worm: There are 2 head cards that start at opposite corners; the rest of the cards show parts of one or two worm bodies that pass through the card. A connection game, where you race to build you worm up to 5 squares long.

2. Cross Word: Each card has a letter, which you may play on any space, occupied or not. If you complete a word across or down, you get 1 point; if you complete a word in both directions, you get 3 points. Most points when the deck runs out wins.

3. Tick-Tack Whoa: Tic-Tac-Toe, with special "Whoa" cards. You may not play an X on an O or vice versa, but you may play a Whoa card on either one, to prevent your opponent getting 3 in a row, and to free up the space for your cards.
categories: Card Game, Children's Game, Word Game

name: tthagaspili丹: Vopnafj旦r丹ur
description: This trivia game is concentrated on the authors hometown in Iceland, Vopnafjörður. Includes a board with a spiraling track from the edge inwards. Three types of cards are included; questions (players get the card if they answer correctly), information (informative text only) and opportunity (both good and bad). Players progress along the track by the roll of a die.

name: slendingaspilin
description: A set collection game (Memory), where players try to collect sets of four famous persons from Icelandic history. There are 60 cards in 15 categories included. The cards include text and pictures of the persons.

name: Adventure Game Starter Set: Wizard's Bane
description:
Box blurb:

"ADVENTURE GAME STARTER SETS are a complete introduction to the hobby of Fantasy Adventure Gaming, all in one box. Each ADVENTURE GAME STARTER SET contains ten paintable plastic action figures in the standard 25mm size, a set of non-toxic water-based paints with instructions and brush, and a complete set of fast, playable rules for playing out your own fantasy adventures. Even the gaming die is included. (For two or more players, ages 10 and up)."

Each contains two leaflets, one containing the rules and adventure; the other, a painting guide for the miniatures. Though each game has a unique background story and series of encounters, the rules of play are identical. On the last page of the rules leaflet is a promotion for Heritage's soon-to-be-released (at that time) RPG, Swordbearer.

Gameplay consists of running two characters through a series of four encounters (combats). Each side in a combat takes turns. During a turn, all characters on the active side fight, then all characters on the active side may use magic, pick up or throw things, or run away.

Fighting is resolved by cross-indexing the roll of a six-sided die with the letter code of the attacker's weapon (A, B, C or D) on a table corresponding to the defender's armor (which may be light, medium, or heavy) in order to find how much damage, if any, was done to the defender.

The miniatures aren't necessary to play, and aren't even mentioned in the game rules.

name: Huddle
description:
Huddle is a game played while watching an American football game on television. Each player's pawn is a football helmet which is placed on the board to indicate a prediction about what will happen on the next play. At the same time each player wagers chips to the center of board. Based on the outcome of the play, the chips wagered are taken by one or more of the players. Play continues until one player has won all the chips.

Components: Board, 4 Helmets, Chips, Rules
mechanics: Betting and Bluffing, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: Dora the Explorer Follow the Leader
description:
This is a simple children's game in which players flip a coin to determine if they move one or two spaces. On each space they must complete a simple activity, for instance "Flap Your Arms" and "Blink Your Eyes." Each player who is behind the leader must also complete this physical activity. Like most roll-and-move children's games, the first player to the final space wins.

This game was first published in Nick Jr. Magazine cover date April 2009.

name: Santa Fe
description: Players hold cards valued 1,2,3,4,7,8,9,10. These are placed in the middle (one per player per turn), the numbers are added up. A player that can reach 55,66,77,88 or 99 gets a point, the player who breaks 111 gets 5 points. Whoever has most points after 5 rounds, wins. This game was part of Piatnik's 1989 Texas Series.

name: Destination Ireland!
description:
"The Award Winning Souvenir Game" in English & Gaeilige!
The aim of the game is to be the player with the most money at the end of the shift ... if you survive the shift!
The players are taxi drivers collecting money (pound and euro) by moving from destination to destination using dice.
mechanics: Area Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Slam Word Solitaire
description:
A privately-produced word card game that has the rare attribute of only having rules for solitaire play.

There are 88 letter cards in the deck. They are dealt into 3 rows of 4 cards each. At each "turn", make a word from the cards in one row only -- each word must have at least 3 letters, but they don't have to be used in the order they are placed in their row. Remove the word just made from the layout, then replace the cards used with new cards from the deck, and add an extra card at the end of the two rows not used for the word. After the whole deck is dealt out, you may make words from the entire layout, not just from one row.

If at any point you cannot make a word when you need to, you lose. If you use up the entire deck with words, you achieve a Baby Slam. If you use up the deck while always making words from one row only, you achieve a Grand Slam.

name: Wihaa!
description: A simple but fun word game, using three colourful dice and an hourglass. Flip the hourglass and roll the first die, which determines the colour or can give zero or ten points without using the other two dice. The second die determines the starting letter and the third die determines the word length.

name: Tuggin' Puppies
description:
These adorable little mischievous puppies will delight young children and their parents. The puppies have each got a corner of the tablecloth and just won't let go! Players try to make a full burger by stacking up all the trimmings as the playful pups tug the cloth to make the burgers wobble and fall apart. The player with the fullest burger when the time is up gets a bone.

Contents: Electronic Table Base, 16 Dog Bones, 16 Filling Discs, 4 Burger Bun Bases, 4 Burger Bun Lids, Ketchup Bottle Start Button, Table Top, 4 Puppies and Instructions
categories: Action / Dexterity, Animals, Children's Game, Electronic

name: Foul Treachery at St Gertrude's
description:
St Gert’s is under threat! The Ministry is trying to close the 'Naughtiest Girl’s School in all England'. Ministry Spies are disguised as various members of staff, pupils and auxiliary staff and if you don’t find them quickly then Old Gerty will close her hallowed doors forever! House captains, it is up to you to root out these insidious goodie-goodies and SAVE THE SCHOOL!

… unless of course you are secretly working for the ministry... then it is your duty to the Minister and the crown to wipe that so called educational establishment from off the map!

In this partially co-operative game players play actions and vote to eliminate one character from the school each round in an attempt to fulfil their various Hidden agendas and the wider game goal of saving the school (or not!). Influence within the school is won and lost during play making the characters in your House Team more or less powerful when it comes down to the vote.

Suspicion is high in the halls and cloisters of St Gert’s…use that to your advantage.
categories: Bluffing, Card Game, Deduction, Humor, Negotiation
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Hand Management, Memory, Open Drafting, Voting

name: Jump Horse
description: The object of the game is to be the first person to win $10,000 and 10 Blue Ribbons. The game is based on real live events at a horse show.

name: Tiere in Gefahr
description: This is a Lotto variant. In the basic version, it is just regular Lotto with pictures of endangered animals. In a variant, players need to answer some quiz questions about the animals if they want to score a point (get a card).

name: Pedigree: A Genealogy Game
description:
Pedigree - A Genealogy Game is a deduction game similar to Clue with an LDS religious theme and simplified rules for children. Players are looking for a missing genealogical record by identifying the name of the person, the type of record, and the building it is located in (a random card of each type is hidden under the board while the others are dealt evenly to the players).

The game uses a spinner instead of dice and players guess if they will spin a high or low number before they can take their turn. As players move about the board, they question each other to determine which cards are under the board. The first person to do so is the winner.

name: Soldiers of Stannum
description:
Soldiers of Stannum is an introductory set of simple miniatures rules designed to allow children and parents to play together. The rules are extremely flexible as to the types of miniatures used, i.e. superhero action figures can compete against medieval fantasy figures. Most rules are designed around the size of the miniature figure - for example, figures can move 3x their standing base length in a turn. Combat rules are resolved around a simple rock-paper-scissors method for hand-to-hand combat and shooting rubber bands or rolling balls for ranged combat.

Throughout the rulebook are reminders that this is a wargame for young children so it is appropriate to let them reshoot misfired shots or make forgotten movements. The goal of the game is to have fun with your children - not slaughter them with your superior gaming skills.

name: Trap Shot
description: This is a dexterity game, where players attempt to flip coins (intended for pennies), but dimes and nickels work great as well. The catapult mechanism is a little unique. It is on the far side of the board and players maneouver the catapult by remote with string. Then players flip the coins back towards them on the board trying to hit one of the nine scoring zones. Different games are included, like high score, or first to hit all zones, etc. This game has a nice wood construction with an approximately 24 inch wood board, built up score zones, and metal rails for the wood coin catapult to travel on.

name: Spell Power
description:
A somewhat canasta-like word card game for 4 players in two partnerships.

The deck has 56 letter cards, in various colors. Each letter of the alphabet appears at least once, in red. If there's a second card, it's blue; if a third, it's green; if a fourth, it's brown. (There is a fifth 'E', which is also red.)

Six cards are dealt to each player, and the top card of the draw pile is exposed to start the discard pile. In a turn a player:
1. Draws either two cards from the draw pile, or the entire discard pile. If the latter, the top discard must be used immediately to form a new word, and the rest are put in the hand.
2. Plays any words out of hand that have at least 3 letters. Previous words may be lengthened to make new words by adding letters at either end; if an opponent's word is lengthened, it becomes your. You may also start a word in hopes that your partner could complete it in his turn; incomplete words may not be stolen.
3. Discards 1 card.

Once he has spelled at least two full words, a player may go out by emptying his hand. The game also ends when the deck is exhausted, and the active player ends his turn.

Each word scores 1 point per letter, doubled if the word has only 2 colors in it, tripled if only 1 color. One point is subtracted for each card left in the hand. The team with the higher score wins.

name: A Game of Words
description:
A rummy-like word card game.

The deck of letters has 5 of each vowel (with red ink front and back), and 4 of each consonant (blue ink); plus a blank card, presumably used to replace a missing one.

The vowels and consonants are shuffled into separate piles; 5 vowels are dealt to each player, and 7-12 consonants. In a turn, a player tries may spell word from his hand, or add to a previous word. He may also trade a card by putting one fro his hand under the appropriate pile (vowel or consonant), and drawing the top card of the pile. (It doesn't say, but presumably one draws replacement cards at the end of one's turn.)

One point per card played is earned. The game ends when all or out of cards but one player, or when no one can play. Highest total wins.

name: Letre Deck
description:
"Challenging games for all ages.

"Create your own exciting card game."

A deck for word card games. It has 52 cards, including 2 wild cards; the rest have a letter with a value as a small subscript. The values range 1-5, with rarer letters worth more.

It comes with rules for Letre Deck Rummy, Letre Deck Solitaire, Letre Deck Pick Up, and Letre Deck Poker.

name: Crossword Card Game
description:
A card game in which players build a crossword on the table. There are 52 cards, each with one letter on it.

NOTE: This specific game with 52 cards, with no point values on the cards, was only published by "Cross Word Co".
The similarly-named game published by Russell Manufacturing, with (48, 64, or 96) cards with point values, belongs on a separate page here: Crossword Letter Game (AKA "Game of Crossword: Cross Word Cards", "Cross Letters Game", "Russell's Fun Cross Word Letter Card Game", and "Crossword Card Game: Cross Word Cards").
publishers: Cross Word Co., Russell Manufacturing Company

name: IT Came from Outer Space
description:
In this game, one player is an alien monster who has gotten aboard a spaceship, and the other controls the crew of the ship - as the back of the game says, it is "a simulation of one of those 'B' grade science-fiction movies of the 50s."

The crew has a number of different weapons they can use against the monster, but they don't know how effective each one will be and some of them can damage the crew or the ship. They can potentially repair the ship if it does get damaged. They also have to manage the ship's power, which must be allocated each turn to various systems.

At the start of the game the monster player gets to allocate points to various areas: strength, movement, concealment, life level, and defense against each possible kind of attack - which is why the crew player does not know how effective a weapon is until they try it.

name: Panzertaktik
description:
From the designers' notes:

"Panzertaktik is a platoon level game covering the major powers in the ETO/MTO between 1939-45. It takes the hardware approach to design, allowing players to make the best (or worst) of the best situations: unlimited intelligence, tireless troops, everlasting ammunition and fuel."

Panzertaktik is a fairly detailed game. Many units (generally representing 5 or so vehicles) have primary and secondary weapons, with separate classifications, strengths and ranges for each. There are rules for artillery, air power, night fighting, minefields, and specialized tanks (Rhinos, flail tanks, etc.), among other things.

Tables of organization and equipment are provided for the American, British, French, Soviet, German, and Italian forces for 1939-45.

name: tthagaspili丹: Flj坦tsdalsh辿ra丹
description: An expansion to tthagaspili丹: Vopnafj旦r丹ur - a box with questions about the Fljótsdalshérað community in the east of Iceland.

name: tthagaspili丹: Hafnarfj旦r丹ur
description: An expansion to tthagaspili丹: Vopnafj旦r丹ur - a box with questions about the town of Hafnarfjörður in Iceland.

name: tthagaspili丹: Vestmannaeyjar
description: An expansion to tthagaspili丹: Vopnafj旦r丹ur - a box with questions about the Vestmannaeyjar Islands in Iceland.

name: tthagaspili丹: Flj坦tsdalsh辿ra丹 aukaspurningar
description: An expansion to tthagaspili丹: Vopnafj旦r丹ur - a small box with bonus questions about the Fljótsdalshérað community in the east of Iceland.

name: Myndalott坦 B鱈nu
description: This game is meant for young children to exercise their listening skills, increase vocabulary and communication skills and make them interested in the alphabet.

name: Scacchetto
description:
This is a chess variant utilizing a 17x12 board. The board also has two blank unpassable areas on it similar to traditional Stratego boards. The game is played with 8 bishops, 8 knights, and 1 king per player.

At the beginning of the game the pieces are placed on the opposite long edges of the game board:
The King is placed on the space marked with a crown.
The knights are placed on the light spaces and the bishops on the dark spaces.

The pieces move like their counterparts in chess, but even the knight may not jump over occupied spaces. The only exception is the center space, marked with a crown. It may only be occupied by a king and only then other pieces may pass this space.

The goal of the game is to beat the enemy king or to take him prisoner. The later being the case if the king is not able to make a move without moving to a space where he may be beaten by an enemy piece.

name: Las Navas de Tolosa
description:
This wargame recreates the turning point in the Spanish "reconquista" against the Muslim occupation in 1212. Still it took three more centuries to conquer the remaining kingdom of Granada, but from this battle onwards the Muslim armies weren't in position to defeat the christian kingdoms any longer.

On one side were the Almohades with their Califfa and his army and his famous bodyguard of chained slaves. On the other were the Kings of Castilla and Navarra with their armies. Sancho "el Fuerte", King of Navarra, himself cut with his sword the slaves chain in order to reach the Califfa's tent. Still nowadays Navarra's shield is a set of chains on a red field remaining this fact of arms.

It was the first modern wargame ever published in Spain by the Spanish company NAC. It's print run was minimum, and it's impossible to find even a picture of it.

The game system could be considered "classic NAC" hex-and-counters with combat and movement factors and a dice with no 1 or 6 instead two 3 and two 4. You multiply the dice by the combat factors involved in each side and eliminate the looser side. All other wargames published by NAC in the following year used this system just changing the pictures.

Fue el primer wargame publicado por NAC, lo tuve en mis manos a los nueve años, pero me compré un Colditz, cuando volví ya no estaba.

Si alguien lo tiene por favor haga algunas fotos y las cuelgue aqui.

Siempre lo busqué y nunca lo encontré por eso diseñé mi juego sobre esta batalla

name: Tic Tac Phone
description: Learn using numbers and letters on a phone. Several educational games for Ages 8 and up.

name: CoDi
description:
CoDi is a game about majorities in a dodecahedron for 2-4 players. The board depicts the 20 corners of the dodecahedron and each corner is connected to exactly 3 other corners.

On his turn the player puts a stone of his color on one of the 20 corners. Stones from other colors on neighbouring corners are removed if the played stone if there already was a stone of the other player's color adjacent to them before.

The game ends when all 20 corners have stones on them with the player with the most stones on the board being the winner.

name: Scherbennova: Erste Welle des Untergangs
description:
A German fantasy themed card game along the lines of Magic the Gathering or Blue Moon.

Two players are dueling each other with custom build decks. A deck contains 15 cards. The game is played on a play-mat which can be downloaded from the games website. Players use portals to bring cards onto the play-mat. Once a card is in play it can be moved and it can be used for attacking opponent cards. If a player is able to destroy an opponents card, he will be awarded a specific amount of shards. Whoever reaches a certain amount of shards first, wins the game.

Website: http://www.scherbennova.de

name: Twilight City: Dark Mysteries
description:
Twilight City: Dark Mysteries is a game of investigation and lovecraftian Mythology. Each player represents an investigator that was summon to the city in order to uncover a mystery. Each mystery is a game in itself for there is a set of original events that describe something that is happening as well as an original background different from the other stories. This is a game of story telling as well, because beyond the generic encounter the investigators will be able to interact with the system in several ways: bribing, buying, paying, taking buses, walking, fighting, healing. Also there is the mechanic of Day and Night that make the encounters relevant both in information and in danger.

All the stories will be written so they lead to a thrilling conclusion and each event will have as much atmosphere as possible. Players will feel as their investigator is wounded and need to move to the hospital, or if they need to reach to someplace at a specific time of the day to retrieve some information. Still finishing a story won't mean to render that story useless. Since the puzzle the investigators have to complete is random, the replayability is unlimited.

The nights in the Twilight City are very dangerous but there is no time to waste for the evil forces are always plotting for the doomsday and if you take too much time you will certainly fail.

The board has generic places that will be referred in the events with their own names. For example: "Go to the abandoned "WAREHOUSE" and meet Herb "The Rat" at 5 o'clock (AFTERNOON). He knows what's going on in the house of the terrible old man (OLD HOUSE)". This way you know you have to go to the WAREHOUSE at any time in the AFTERNOON. But you won't find Herb "The Rat" at any other time. So time is essential to the plot. And the board serves to shape a new city with every dark mystery.
categories: Exploration, Fantasy, Murder/Mystery, Print & Play, Puzzle
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Role Playing, Roll / Spin and Move, Storytelling

name: House by the Cemetery
description:
After an accident attempting to avoid a pedestrian in the road, you soon realize there is something terribly wrong with the "pedestrian" which caused your crash. One of his eye sockets drips maggots upon his cheek as he staggers toward you... And he is not alone!

Make your way to the military compound on the outskirts of this town. Each move closer uncovers more of the undead horde; and once they sense your presence, they want your flesh. You will need to find weapons if you wish to survive, and you will need to rescue the few remaining survivors if you want to be a hero.

name: Rallycross
description: The Ultimate Game in Rallycross driving. Players take turns to roll dice to race around the track. Players pick up cards for hazards and for a bonus. The race ends when a player has completed 3.5 laps.

name: A.B.C. Educational Cards
description:
This 36-card deck is a simple means for helping small children learn letters and numbers. There is one card for each letter of the alphabet, and one for each numeral 1-10. On the back is the letter or number, on the front the same with an illustration (e.g. Z "zebra" with a picture of a zebra; or "5 balls" with a picture).

Simple games include:

- Simple Spelling Game. Spread out the letter cards, and pick out the first and last letter of a common word, e.g. C-T. Let the child figure out what goes in between, with help if necessary.

- Easy Counting. Have the child count the items out loud on the illustrated side, or have two numbers and have them figure out what the sum is.

Some editions have rules for advanced games:

- A.B.C. Rummy. Deal 7 cards to each player. In a turn, draw 1, lay down 3 or more consecutive letters or numbers and/or add to existing sequences, and discard 1. First one out cards wins 5 points per card in others' hands.

- A.B.C. Kasino. Deal 4 to each player and 4 face up in the middle. In a turn a player plays a card to the table, capturing other cards if adjacent to them, or leaving it there if unable to capture. After the cards are played out, deal 4 more each, etc., until all cards are played. Remaining cards go to the last capturer. Most cards captured wins.

- Snip & Snap. Deal the deck to 2 players, who take turns exposing the top card in their pile. They "Snip" each time, unless the card is adjacent to the opponent's last card, when he says "Snap" and captures his whole face-up pile. Continue until someone has all the cards.
categories: Card Game, Children's Game, Educational, Number, Word Game

name: Game of Word Making
description:
A very early word game, somewhat like 5 card draw poker without the wagering.

There are 48 letter cards; 5 are dealt to each player, and each in turn gets one chance to discard any number of cards and receive an equal number from the deck. Then hands are scored: 3, 4 or 5 points for a 3, 4 or 5-letter word; -1 if it's a plural that ends in 'S'; +10 for each hard letter (Q, V, W, X, Y, Z) in the word (the cards are labeled as hard); or 20 points for 3 of a kind (UUU), 50 points for 4 of a kind (OOOO). Play to an agreed amount of time, hands, or points; the highest score wins.

name: Rootie Kazootie Word Game
description:
This is a children's word game that licenses the popular TV show of the early 1050's, "The Rootie Kazootie Club".

The deck has 6 Key Cards, each of which has two words (e.g. Wagon, Duck). There are 30 letter cards with a letter and an illustrating picture and sentence (e.g. "O o Rootie watches a night Owl"); the 30th card, "Magic Kazootie" is a wild card and can stand for any letter. (The deck does not have the entire alphabet, only letters needed for the Key Card words.)

Five cards are dealt to each player, and the top Key Card turned up. In a turn, a player draws 1 and discards 1. If he can make one of the Key words, the hand ends and he gets the points that the word is worth. Play to an agreed number of rounds.
categories: Card Game, Children's Game, Novel-based, Word Game

name: Lightning Bolts & Lasers
description: Subtitled: Science Fiction Miniature Tactics Manual. This 80 page book is a supplement for Starguard. It includes information on military organization, a chapter on tactics, TO&Es for Starguard races, a few new race designs, a Starguard Histories Update authored by John McEwan, armored fighting vehicles, and appendices on weapon ranges, stats for a variety of weapons, and starter sets.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Science Fiction, Wargame

name: T.H.E. Cat Game
description: This game from 1966 is based on a television show from that time which starred Robert Loggia. It is a simple track game where you must be the last to survive in the game.

name: Mr. Magoo visits the Zoo
description: Simple child's game of animal recognition.

name: Political Pursuit
description: A political trivia game that claims to be educational, fun, entertaining and filled with excitement. You move around the board answering political questions that get you points. Most points gets you elected to office!

name: Gabble
description:
A gin-rummy-like word card game. There is a deck of 50 letter cards, 2 Consonant cards, 1 Vowel card, and 1 Wild card, that stand for any consonant, any vowel, and any letter respectively. There's also a scoring pad with point summaries.

Ten cards are dealt to each player. In a turn, a player draws 1 from the draw or discard pile, and either goes out by melding all 11 cards into words of 3+ letters each, or discards a card. Once a player goes out, each other player gets one turn to draw and make their best melds.

Players try for the lowest score. Points for words melded:
0 points for 3 or 4 letters; -5 points for 5 letters; -10 for 6; -15 for 7; -20 for 8; -25 for 9; -30 for 10; -5 for each J, K, Q, X, or Z used; and 11-letter word wins the whole game outright. Penalties include: +10 points for not going out; +10 for each unused vowel, or Vowel or Consonant card; +5 for each unused consonant, except for J, K, X, Z which are +1. There is also a system for challenging a word, and re-challenging if the challenged player is confident, that lead to bonuses or penalties.

The last player to +100 points wins.

name: Letter Pile
description:
Gameplay revolves around sixty transparent tiles. Each tile has a letter printed on it in caps. Each player must make a word of up to five letters that has no letters repeated from the seven letters each player was dealt. Each player must also construct a crossword puzzle type clue for the word composed. A player may bluff if a word can't be constructed with the tiles dealt. The words are placed in the holder so that the letters of each individual word overlap. Players score points for deducing opponent’s words. The game is played until a goal the players have agreed upon is reached.

Game components: four letter holders with rack, sixty letter tiles, one clue and a three-minute sand timer.

name: The Chase
description:
A realistic game based on the Laws of Nature for the entire family, nature lovers, the young student of nature, and for the hunter.
The game includes a large, nicely illustrated gameboard, tokens for the rabbits and hounds that stand in wooden holders, and 40-page handbook, extensively documenting the hazards encountered in the game, from a real-life nature perspective, with dozens more illustrations.

name: SpellBusters
description:
from the back of the box:

How well can you spell everyday words when the timer is running an everyone is "Looking Over Your Shoulder"?

Spellbusters is more than just spelling! There are also multiple choice questions about subjects we all should know.

However, it's not just what you know, it's what you think the other players know. Should you play with them... or against them?

... Play your chips right and you can be the winner!

name: P.O.B
description:
P.O.B is a tile laying taxi game for 2-4 players.

Rival taxi firms compete to be the first to pick up 5 passengers and return to the Taxi Rank.

A road network is built by laying tiles. Taxis drive down roads, crossing multiple tiles at times, and only stop when they reach a Stop line, Zebra Crossing or to pick up a passenger. After deploying their opponent's passengers, players can then re-deploy their opponent's passengers as the game progresses.

name: Number Busters
description:
This collectible/educational game consists of various plastic miniatures, each with a battle card. There is a starter pack which contains 10 miniatures and 10 cards, and various two- and four-creature expansion packs.

Creatures fall into one of four categories: Fire, Earth, Water, or Space.

Each miniatures has a secret number printed on the bottom - different copies of the same miniature will have different numbers - thus making it a "collectible" game.

There are three different levels of play, for various ages ranges, but all involve a little math, making it "educational".

Description from Little Tikes:

Step into a world where survival is an every day battle. In this world of Creatures, bigger isn't always better. In this world brains wins out over brawn every time.


Each character has a random number on their foot.



Players use numbers to face off and try to knock each other's characters out.



Fierce and fun pre-historic creature characters engage kid's imaginations.



Competitive game play so simple and exciting - kids won't even know they are learning.



Each character features its own collectible trading card.
categories: Animals, Card Game, Children's Game, Collectible Components, Educational, Math, Miniatures
mechanics: Simultaneous Action Selection, Variable Player Powers

name: Fairway Fanatics Trivia
description:
This is a golf trivia board game. Players move from the Tee Time space to the 19th Hole space as they answer questions about the sport of golfing. There are adult and "junior" questions with different levels of difficulty.

Includes a colorful board, 4 unique golf ball tokens, 2 special dice, and two question booklets.

name: Triade
description: 18 round wooden tiles (numbered 1-6 in three different colors) are face-down on the table. Players roll three dice (in the three colors) and have to find the exact tiles thus determined, memory style. Whoever finds the determined combination first, gets one victory point, then the tiles are shuffled again. Whoever gets four victory points first, wins.

name: Stakato
description: This is a kind of chess game on the three-dimensional game board which has to be assembled from cardboard components before the first game. The winning condition is to either reach the highest square of the field ("throne") with the king or to check-mate the opponent's king. Other player's pawns cannot be eliminated, though. Besides the king, the "pawns" are dice with different symbols. These change the movement rules (by turning a different side up) each time they are jumped over or jump over other pawns.
mechanics: Grid Movement, Point to Point Movement

name: Star Corps Companion
description:
A supplement to Star Corps: Call to Battle in a 40 page 5.5" x 8.5" booklet including 2 8.5" x 11" revised and updated weapons tables. The booklet includes a section on history, rules for adding powered armor, detailed information on a new force (The Amana Recon Rangers), new trooper types, updated rules, an alien creation system, and conversions for using miniatures from other manufacturers.


http://www.teamfrog.com/fig-sc.htm
categories: Miniatures, Science Fiction, Space Exploration, Wargame

name: Galaxias
description:
(From the instruction booklet) "Galaxias is a space-age game of strategy in which a player must conquer all of the Galaxies in the Universe. Galaxias takes the basic principles of classic war games and modernizes them to fit the 20th century."
Essentially 'Risk in Space': countries have become planets, continents are now galaxies, armies are squadrons. Controlling an entire galaxy entitles you to extra squadrons on your turn. Conquering a planet nets you a card with one of three symbols: A space shuttle, a ring-type space station, or a spaceship similar to the one from "2001: A Space Odyssey". Turning in a set of three gives you more squadrons. The squadrons are triangular craft beads that can be stacked.
There are also 2 'Black Hole' cards, 1 'Death Ray', and 1 'Laser Shield'.
Instead of a folding board, the universe is represented by a roll-up mat, which is stored in a cardboard tube, along with the cards and squadrons.
There are four dice total: two each of two colors.
The game was designed and manufactured in Tulsa, Oklahoma.
mechanics: Area Movement, Dice Rolling, Set Collection

name: The Black 7
description:
The game consists of cards numbered 3 to 11. The 7 is placed in the middle, the others in a circle around it. The player whose turn it is, rolls two dice and places a chip on the card with the value rolled. If there is a chip already, he/she can take it instead. If someone rolls a 7, though, he/she always has to place a chip, on rolling a two or twelve, one can take all chips (in case of the two, except the ones on the 7). The last player to still hold chips, wins. The chips are not included in the game material.
This was one of six games in Piatnik's 1989 Texas Series

name: Faculty Cards
description:
This is a somewhat canasta-like word card game. The deck has 108 cards, of which 6 are wild, and the rest have a letter and value. 15 cards each are dealt for 2 players, 13 for 3, 11 for 4; the top of the draw pile is turned over to start the discard pile.

In a turn, a player:
1. Draws two cards from the draw pile; or he may draw the top discard if he melds it immediately and places it the rest of the discard pile in his hand.
2. Melds cards from his hand onto the table. A meld is a word of 3+ letters, and fewer wild cards than letter cards. His first meld must be one word worth 15+ points; after that he may meld any valid word and/or place cards at either end of a previous meld to make new words.
3. Discard one to the discard pile.

A hand ends when a player empties his hand by melding or discarding. Each player scores: 50 points for each word with a value of 15 or more, 10 points for lesser words; a bonus of 50 for going out; and a penalty of double the value of the cards left in hand. The overall game is won at 1000 points.

name: Gin-A-Word
description:
Oklahoma Gin Rummy with words. The deck has 70 cards, each with a letter and a point value between 1 and 10. Ten cards are dealt each player, and the top card turned over to start the discard pile. This is also the "knock" card, and determines the value you must match to knock.

In a turn a player draws the top of either pile and either goes out or discards one. If a player can form his hand into a 10- or 11-letter word, he calls "Gin-A-Word" and goes out; if he can make 10 letter into 2 or more words of 3+ letters each, he calls "Gineroo" and goes out; if he can meld all his hand together except cards whose total value is

name: Octaquad
description:
Octaquad is a print and play space combat game. The game is fairly simple to learn and involves some rather unique rules. The board itself is essentially made from the space ships. Normal rules allow for 1 player per ship, but the players can mix and match however they want.

Each ship is an octagon-shaped tile, and each tile must always be touching the rest of the tiles. Players can perform special tricks to position themselves in different places on the board, but these tricks can fail to succeed. Positioning, facing, planning, and luck are all part of the game.

The basic rules right now are just for normal ship-to-ship combat.
categories: Abstract Strategy, Print & Play, Science Fiction

name: Players in the dating game
description:
THIS IS A VERY SIMPLE CARD GAME.

The toy box comes alive during the day
in the hands of children as they play.
As the night grows dim and our children lay,
the toy box comes alive and with each other they play.

It’s perhaps the most dangerous game of all
as players in the dating game you will lie, cheat, steal, and then lie some more. This is a game based on reading your opponent’s bluff, finding out who has the ultimate arm candy and then stealing her right from under them.
Where dating more than one woman is the easy part but keeping your friends rivals from
moving in on your turf can end in tears.

PRINT & PLAY FILES ARE UPLOADED.

name: Front Page
description:
The object of this game is to compose the front page of the "Main Street Herald." Upon completion of the page, the player with the highest score, earned by completing stories and winning bonuses, wins the game.

The game simulates the editorial and layout tasks in putting a newspaper together: there are tiles for headlines, photos, photo captions, inside text (shown as rows of horizontal lines, as a designer would represent in thumbnail), jumps and so on. It is a word game only in a very limited sense: some of the headlines and captions span more than one tile, so you must assemble the phrases properly for the layout to make sense.

The page is laid out on a game board with different regions providing different scores. There are also methods for players to challenge one another, based on the filing times for stories, story shape, position and so forth.

The game includes decks of City Desk cards, Wire Service cards and Clock cards (one for each hour from 10 AM to midnight). The cards trigger events and bonus points.
mechanics: Chit-Pull System, Hand Management, Open Drafting, Tile Placement

name: Intelex
description:
The deck is modeled after the traditional card deck: there are 52 cards, with the suit and rank in the corner, along with a letter and the letter's value (1 to 15, rarer letters higher). There are also 2 "Intelex" cards which act as jokers/wild cards. Rules for 4 games are included:

Word Rummy: Deal 10 each for 2 players, 7 each for 3-4, 6 each for 5-6. In a turn, a player draws 1 from the draw or discard pile, lays down words, adds letters to others' words, and discards 1. The player who goes out scores the total of the letters' values in front of him; the others subtract the values of letters still in hand.

Discovery: Hangman for 4 players. Deal out the whole deck (without the Intelex cards). Each player makes a word out of his cards and lays them face down in a row, with his word spelled in order among them. In a turn, a player repeatedly asks 1 other player if they have a specific letter; if they do, they expose all copies of that letter they have. The turn ends when a request fails. During a turn one may also guess what a word is: if wrong, he loses 5 point; if right, he gets the word's score and the guess-ee is out for the hand, which ends when all words are discovered. One may bluff and have no word; if that is correctly the guesser gets 20 points.

Solitaire: Like Klondike. Deal out 7 stacks of cards, of heights 1, 2 ... 7, the top card of each face up. Move cards around to form words and word fragments, removing words as they are formed, exposing face-down cards as revealed, filling blank spots with letters or fragments. Then go through the deck 3 cards at a time, combining letters as before. The goal is to use up the whole deck.

Poker: For 2 to 7. Deal 5 per player. Each in turn may exchange any or all of their cards for an equal number from the deck, and make their best word. Highest-scoring word wins. (Betting and bluffing are mentioned as on option "for added excitement".)

name: Wir bauen einen Zoo
description: There are tiles which can be puzzled together to form a picture of a zoo. Each player can place one tile onto the table plus as many tiles as there are eyes (human or animal eyes) in the first tile he or she placed. The player to get rid of his or her tiles first, wins.

name: Word Rummy
description:
There are 52 cards, each with a letter and a value between 1 and 10, plus two wild cards with value 0.

Deal 9 cards per player, and turn up the top of the stock to start the discard pile. In a turn, a player draws 1 from either pile, lays down any words from his hand and/or lays off cards on existing words to make new words, and discards 1 card. The game ends when a player depletes their hand with their discard.

Each player scores the total of all cards in front of him or her, adds bonuses (10 points for going out, 5 for a 6+ letter word, 5 for laying off on another player's word), and subtracts the value of all cards left in hand. Highest score wins.

name: Trivia of Tulsa
description: Trivia game printed as a promotional item

name: Winning on Wall Street
description:
Winning on Wall Street is a stock game with a spinner. Players buy stock then use the spinner to determent if the stock goes up or down. The 30 stocks used represent the Dow-Jones stocks as of May 1998.
"Can YOU Beat the Market?"

Contents include: 20x22 tri-fold gameboard with spinner, 30 leading Wall Street stocks, paper money, score pad, dice, and Wall Street calculator.

name: Wolken-Spiel
description: There are tiles with clouds in the shape of animals, and matching tiles with pictures of those animals. The cloud tiles are placed face down on the game board ("sky"), from the stack of animals, two tiles are flipped open. The player whose turn it is, flips one of the cloud tiles. If it is one of the open animals, he or she will get the animal tile as a point and the cloud remains open for the remainder of the game. If it isn't, it's the next player's turn. But after each move, a player may also move one open cloud tile one square to the right, even on top of other tiles, which then cannot be opened until the wind moves to card on top of them.

name: House of Deduction
description:
House of Deduction is a light deduction game for four players. Each player has one card in front of them and, on their turn, asks another player to reveal one of the shapes on their card or turn their card 90 degrees in an attempt to connect one of each shape at the point where all four cards touch.

House of Deduction was created for Mike Barlow's "4 cards or tiles only" contest.

name: Word-O-Gram
description:
The deck has 54 cards: 52 letter cards with a value 2-10, and 2 jokers worth 15. There are 4 games described:

Cross Words: Deal 10 each for 2-4 players, 8 each for 5, 7 for 6, 6 for 7. In a turn a player lays down a word, or discards 1 and draws 1. No more than 4 cards can be played in a turn, and all cards played must be in the same row or column, forming a typical crossword pattern, so all adjacent letters form a word. The hand ends when a player empties his hand, and all others add the values of their remaining cards to their total. Game ends when someone reaches 100 points, and the lowest total wins.

Speed Game: Like Cross Words, except that a 4- or 5-letter word is place on the table to start, and there are no turns: when the signal is given, players add words to the array, or discard and draw, when they wish.

Solitaire 1: Make 12 piles of 3, all face up and fanned to see the lower cards. Discard cards by forming words from the top cards of the piles -- but you can use a lower card if the card(s) above it are also used in the same word. When you've done all you can, take the remaining cards and turn them up in 3s, using them to make more words with the rest. You can go through the deck as often as you want. You win if you use all the cards.

Solitaire 2: Deal out 6 cards face up, and expose the top card of the remaining deck. Make words out of the cards, discarding them when made, and fill in empty slots from the deck. You lose if you get stuck.

name: Lingo
description:
This is one of many competing crossword card games of the late 1930s. Fairchild had two versions: Lingo used bridge-size cards, and Patch Word had small cards to more easily fit on the table. The deck has 54 cards consisting of 2 jokers and 52 letter cards.

The rules for the Cross Word game: Deal 11 each for 2-3 players, 9 for 4-5, 7 for 6 or more. Each player lays down a word in their turn, using no more than 4 cards, and adding to the growing crossword arrangement. If they cannot play a word, they discard 1 and draw 1 from the draw or discard pile. The hand ends when a player goes out of cards, and players add the values of their cards in hand to their total; commoner cards have higher values. When a player reaches 100 total points, the low score wins.

The Lingo version had rules for 3 other games:

Lingo-Anagram: For 2-4 players. Deal 10 each. In a turn, a player either lays down a word of 3+ letters, or adds letters to an existing word to make new words, or does neither; the turn ends by discarding 1 and drawing 1 card. Adding simple endings (-S, -ES, -ED) is prohibited. The hand ends and the game scored as in the cross word game.

Scrambled-Lingo: Have all agree on a length of word to make. Spread all the cards on the table, and players draw that number of cards for a particular word. Then they scramble its order and pass it to the left. Players announce when they have unscrambled the word and lay it down. The order of correct unscrambling is the order of winning.

Lingo-Solitaire: Take the cards that make your full name, or a short phrase. See how many ways you can rearrange all the letters to make a phrase that makes sense.
publishers: All-Fair Toys and Games (Alderman-Fairchild Co.), E. E. Fairchild Corporation

name: Hex Races
description:
Hex Races is a race around the outside of a track consisting of four hex tiles with different colors on each side. Each pawn races clockwise starting on its own base. The race ends when one pawn returns to its own base after one lap. This race is for 2-4 players. The challenge is that the tiles may be moved throughout the race, making the path longer or shorter at any given moment.

The components consist of one six-sided die, 2-4 pawns of different colors and four hex tiles to be printed out.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Modular Board, Roll / Spin and Move

name: The Game of Words
description:
A crossword card game of the late 1930s, that also includes rules for several other games, a few of which were not seen in its competitors. The deck has 54 cards: 2 "Sub" cards which act as wild cards, and 52 cards with a letter and its value on each. Rules for 8 games are included:

1. Crossword Game: Deal 10 each to 2-4, 7 each to 5-7 players. In each turn, a player lays a word from his hand to the table in a crossword fashion, the first word alone, other words intersecting the growing array. If unable to play, a player discards 1 and draws 1 from the draw or discard pile. A hand ends when a player goes out; players add their hands' value to their scores; when a player reaches 100 the low total wins.

2. Word Solitaire: Lay all the cards face up in 3s, fanned so as to see all the letters. Make and discard words from the topmost cards, though if a card is used in a word the letter just underneath it can also be used. You win if you use all the cards.

3. Letter Patience: Like Klondike, deal 7 piles of heights 1-7, and turn up the top card of each. Make and discard cards, exposing the new tops of each pile; empty spaces may be filled in with vowels. Turn up the remainder of the deck one by one, and use the top letter of this pile with the others to make words. You win if you use all the cards.

4. Crossword Solitaire A: Deal out 6 cards face up. Use these cards to build a crossword array, one word at a time, filling empty spaces in the 6 from the remaining deck. Then turn up that deck one at a time and continue -- you can only use the top of the turn-up pile.

5. Crossword Solitaire B: Similar to A, but start with a hand of 12 cards, which is not replenished; the deck is still gone through once, one card at a time.

6. Anagrams: For 1-6 players. Everyone is dealt one card. In a turn, a player either: places his card in the center of the table; makes a word with that card and other cards in the center, placing the word in front of him; or adds the letter to an existing word, rearranging letters to make a new word, and taking the word if it belonged to someone else. After the deck has been gone through, the player with the most points in front of him wins.

7. The O-U-T Game: For 4-8 players. All the cards are dealt face up. In a turn a player places one card in the middle of the table, while thinking of a word of at least 9 letters that starts with all the letters placed so far. Once such a word is finished, the player who does it gets a letter (O, U or T), the word is discarded and the process starts again. On getting all of OUT, a player is out of the game. A player may pass if they think they don't have a letter to add to the growing word; if someone else points out a letter and word he could do, he earns an E for excellence, which can cancel out one other letter. Players may challenge a play that doesn't seem to lead to any word; whoever is wrong earns a penalty letter.

8. Guess-O-Gram: A type of hangman for any number of players. One becomes the Thinker, thinks of a word, and lays it face down in order. Other take turns guessing letters; if a letter is in the word it is revealed and the guesser earns 2 points per letter. A player who guess the whole word or the last letter gets 2 points times the length of the word. Play to an agreed number of rounds.

name: Make the Middle
description:
You will need:

A 6-sided die
Paper and pencil
An egg timer/sand timer
A token for each player (optional)

How to Play:

Each player gets a pair of the tiles. Player one places one in front of them, and rolls the die. The die roll tells them which letter will be in play this game. 1 = top letter, 2 = second letter down, and so on. (Optional: Place a coin or token next to this letter to mark it, or write it on your paper.)

Player one sets the second tile down to the left of the first. They roll the die again, and the letter from the second tile is chosen as with the first. Player one then takes the second tile and overlaps the first, so that the two active letters are side by side.

Player two determines their active letters the same way. The timer is started, and players list as many words as possible that start with the left letter and end with the right.

When time runs out, the player with more words scores the difference in the number of words between the two players.

If player one makes 10 words and player two makes 7, player one scores 3 points.

For the next round, each player must rotate a tile, change the order of the tiles, or perform any combination of the two.

First player to 20 points wins.

To increase the intensity, increase the required number of letters per word to 4, 5, or 6.

Created by indigopotter for Reprint's contest, February 2009.

name: Tillos
description:
Placement rules are just like Blokus. Every new piece must touch your existing piece diagonally, and diagonally only. They can touch, or not touch, opponent piece in any manner as long as there are no overlaps.

One player gets the two L pieces, the other the T and the S. Again, like in Blokus, players start from opposite corners. However, unlike Blokus, once a player has placed his two pieces down, he will replace the piece that was not the one last played. The replaced piece must be moved into a different position.

Scoring occurs as follows. For every square of any opponent piece that the newly replaced piece touches, the player scores one point. (For example, if the green player just played the T, he scores two points.)

The game ends when a player has reached 40 points.

name: Start and Swindle
description:
At the beginning of each round, a new pool of VP tokens is added. The number of VP tokens in said pool is determined by a dice roll (2d6).

Starting with the start player, players take turns taking one of the four cards.

They then play them simultaneously, with either the green or the red side face up.

The player who played the highest value of red becomes the start player next round. All other players who played red gets nothing.

Then starting with the player who played the highest value of green, players get to take the number of VP from each separate pool equal to the value of the green card that he played. This continues in descending order of the value of the green cards played.

Pool/s with leftover VPs are left as is going into the next round. (So theoretically there could be any number of pools for each round. If the pools have 6, 4, and 3 tokens, and the highest green played was 4, that player gets to grab 4, 4, and 3 tokens from each pool respectively before anyone else gets to grab anything. Yes it's broken. That's why being the start player is important.)

name: Agiotare Pretium
description:
A Game Created for the 4-Tile Contest
In an old obscure empire, 2 to 4 merchant traders are wandering from town to town, looking to buy goods on the cheap and sell them later for big profit.
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: Hubbub
description:
A traditional game played the Pequot Indians of North America. Each player starts with 5 scoring sticks and tosses five sticks or rocks in a bowl. If all five land with a colored side up a player wins 2 points. If three pieces land with colored side up, a player wins 1 point. Any other combination yields no points. If you win any points, you get to go again. If you don't win points, play passes to the other player. For every point lost, you must give the other player 1 scoring stick. The game ends when one player has no sticks left. During play it is traditional to shout "Hubbub" out-loud. This is where the name of the game derives from.

This game is similar to All-tes-teg-enuk


The American Heritage Dictionary possibly attributes the origin of the word hubbub to this game. Quote:

It has often been remarked that the early Celtic inhabitants of Britain contributed very little to the stock of English words. Perhaps this should not surprise us, given the difficult relations over the centuries between the people of Germanic stock and the people of Celtic stock in England and Ireland. It seems likely that a certain English contempt resides in the adoption of the word hubbub from a Celtic source, which is probably related to ub ub ubub, a Scots Gaelic interjection expressing contempt, or to abu, an ancient Irish war cry. In any case, hubbub was first recorded (1555) in the phrase Irish hubbub and meant "the confused shouting of a crowd." In addition to the senses it has developed, hubbub was again used, possibly in an unflattering way, by the New England colonists as a term for a rambunctious game played by Native Americans.

name: Cross-O-Grams
description:
A crossword card game from the late 1930s during a craze of such games, published by a newspaper company. Its games are a slight twist on the usual rules of its rivals.

There are 54 cards in the deck. 52 of them have a letter and a value from 10 to 50 (the Q card actually has two letters, QU); there are also 2 jokers (wild cards) worth 100.

The rules to 6 games are given:

Cross-O-Grams: For 2+ players (but if 4 or more, 2 decks are recommended). Deal 12 each. In a turn a player either makes a word on the table from his hand, or draws one and passes; if his hand only X, Y or Z he may discard one of those before drawing. Words are at least 2 letters long, and after the first word, new words must intersect or extend previous words, crossword fashion. A hand ends when a player goes out or the draw pile runs out. The value of the cards in hand goes to the winner of the round, and the highest total wins after an agred time; or, players get their own totals in hand at the end of a round, and when one player reaches 500, the lowest total wins.

An-O-Grams: For 2-8 players, but use 2 decks for 4+ players. Deal 12 each. In a turn, a player: plays a word of 3+ letters to the table in front of him; or adds 1+ letters to a word on the table to make it a new word (without changing the letters' order), taking the word to himself; or draws 1 card and passes. Simple endings (-S, -ED, -ER) are forbidden. The round ends when a player goes out or the deck runs out. Each player scores the points in front of him minus the points in hand; a player who goes out before the deck runs out doubles his table points.

Casino-Grams: For 2-4 players. Take out the jokers and deal 4 to each player and 4 face-up to the table. In a turn a player plays one of his cards to the table and does one of the following: A) makes a word with it and other table cards, placing the word in front of him; B) builds toward a future word, combining 1 card with table cards, announcing the letter(s) he has that will be played later; C) steals a word from someone else by adding a letter to it and making a new word; D) leaves it on the table with the other table cards. After the cards are played, 4 more are dealt to each player (but no more to the table), and play continues. After all the cards are played, the one who made or stole the last word gets the remaining table cards. Each player gets 1 point per card he has on the table; the game is won on reaching 100.

Cross-O-Gram Solitaire: Like Klondike, 7 piles are dealt out of height 1-7 cards, the top one exposed. Combine the visible cards to build words into a crossword array. When stuck, start turning the remaining deck 3 at a time and use those cards to continue. (Or, do it 1 at a time, going through the deck only once.) You win if you use up the whole deck.

Cross-O-Gram Double Solitaire: The solitaire above played with 2 players, with decks of different colored backs. Take turns playing until you can play to the table. The game ends when neither can add anything to the crossword, and the one with the most cards out wins.

Canister Solitaire: Deal the whole deck into 8 columns face-up, fanned vertically so you can see what's coming. There will be 6 each in 4 columns, 7 each in the other 4.
